While the"blue-chip" stocks show minuscule rates of growth, evenin an expanding economy, there are stocks experiencing literallyexplosive growth… stocks that double,even triple in value in a matter of a fewweeks… stocks that turned a $100,000investment into over $157,000 in just 6months, from July 1 - December 27, 1996! Now You Can UseThe Same Method To Make 40% – 60% Annual Profits On Your Growth Capital With Reduced Risk With aBlistering 57.45% Gain in 6 Months, Jay Saxena Rockets Ahead of the Market CARY, NC -– Anotherbrainchild of stock-picker, Jay Saxena, Hot Stocks Digest appearsto be on its way to becoming a star performer in the investmentadvisory industry. Saxena’s stellar success with previousnewsletters serves as his springboard for this exclusiveinvestment publication, which started its portfolio on July 1,1996. While NASDAQ composite gainedonly 9% from July to December, the model portfolio published inthe weekly Hot Stocks Digest returned a sizzling 57.45%. Thistremendous performance has far outdistanced all other advisorypublications, mutual funds and professional money-managers. Inspite of the recent poor performance by small-cap stocks, Saxenahas amassed a fantastic 57% return for his understandably loyalfollowers. Dear FellowInvestor, If you think a 20% annual return onyour money is good, here’s how to set your sights on 40% ormore. This is yourpersonal invitation to join aselect group of investors who will double or triple their moneyin the next 2 years. My name is Jay Saxena and I make money formy readers. The model portfolio I feature in my weeklyHot Stocks Digest brought my readers a 57.45% gainin last six months of 1996. And right now, conditions are rightto achieve even greater gains in 1997. For a few minutes lets forget aboutthe Fed, the Dow and the so called experts you see on TV everyday. Instead, lets talk about how you can make hugereturns in the stock market by following my proven Alpha(a )-RSM stock selection system. When you look back in a few months,sitting on profits exceeding your wildest imagination,you’ll be amazed at your tremendous success. Even as mostinvestors are sitting on the sidelines waiting for the nextcrash, here’s your golden opportunity to join a select fewwho are able to soar to new heights of investment successregardless of prevailing market conditions. Think it can’t be done intoday’s market? Well let me tell you. Not only can it bedone, but it is being done by me and readers of my Hot Stocks Digest. My weekly service is specially designed fora few seasoned investors, like yourself, who want average annualreturns in excess of 40%with little effort and minimum hassle. The Hot Stocks Digest model portfolio was started on July 1, 1996. Since then it has generated a 57.45% gain for our readers. During the same time, the Nasdaq was up only 8.98%. It has outperformed the Nasdaq index by over 48 percentage points. Talk about blistering performance! With a proven, high-octane stockselection system, the Hot Stocks Digest couldn’t be any easier to follow. Youmay be one of those few investors who understands that explosivereturns in growth stocks are only made by those who are decisiveand swift. But, to be both decisive and swift requires a lot oftime and a tremendous amount of research. Hot Stocks Digest contains a weekly rankingand model portfolio of the most timely stocks in themarketplace today. It is easy to understand and easy to accessusing the internet or you can get it via fax or e-mail. My Alpha(a )-RSM System incorporates the C-A-N-S-L-I-Mapproach developed by William O’Neil. It is designed toferret out those stocks that have a high alpha as well as highrelative strength & momentum. Alpha is that measure of the returnthat is not explained by the general market. For example, if theS&P500 has an average monthly return of 1.5% and a stock hasan average monthly return of 8.5%, then the stock has an alpha of7%. This 7% is the excess return that the stock generates overthe general market. Once we have selected our list of400+ high alpha stocks, we run them through ourproprietary mathematical models that rank them based on theirrelative strength and momentum. We want to buy only those highalpha stocks that also have high relative strength and are goingup at the present time. We have no interest in stocks that aregoing sideways, or worse, are going down. The "200 Most Attractive Hot Stocks" are then presented in each issue of the HotStocks Digest. Their symbol, Friday’sclosing price, percent change over the past 21 & 50 days and21-day & 50-day moving average values are also shown. You can use this list of the 200 mostattractive hot stocks to pick and choose and build your ownpersonal portfolio. One strategy is to buy stocksthat appear close to the top of that list. Hold a stock as longas it in the list of 200. When a stock drops out of the list,sell it and then buy again from the top of the list. This is just one way of using thelist. You may prefer to use it differently and tailor it to suityour personal taste. Another way to use the list is to buy anystock that makes it to the top 25. To make room in yourportfolio, you may have to sell some stocks. We recommend yousell the lowest ranked stocks and buy the top ranked ones. Thisway you will be rotating out of weaker stocks into stronger ones. Or you may decide to mechanicallyfollow the modelportfolio presented in eachweekly issue of the Hot Stocks Digest. This requires no furtheranalysis or judgment on your part. As a new subscriber you havetwo options when you start building your portfolio. Theaggressive option is to go ahead and buy all stocks in the modelportfolio. This way you'll be fully invested instantly. Even though some of these stocks maybe up 100-200%, it doesn't mean that they cannot go up another100% or more from present levels. The conservative option is tobuy only a few top-ranked stocks each week and leave the rest ofyour portfolio in cash. This way, it'll take you a few weeks tobecome fully invested. You'll receive the HotStocks Digest every Sunday via fax or e-mail. Please accept my compliments for your wonderful andpractical approach to stock selection. — P.E. of New York,NY I employ a combination of fundamentaland technical investment approaches and have a rigid riskmanagement system to keep my reward to risk ratio high. I determine my purchase candidates based on fundamental analysis and time my purchases using technical analysis, recommending the most promising small-cap growth stocks that show strong technical patterns and evidence of accumulation. Some of the fundamental and technicalcharacteristics I look for are accelerating earnings, positiveearnings surprises, accelerating revenues, high relativestrength, high relative industry strength, a low PE relative tothe projected earnings growth rate, innovative products in amarket that is rapidly expanding, rising order backlogs, andexpanding profit margins. I sell when a stock breaks downtechnically or violates my screening rules. Part of this stock selection processuses the C-A-N-S-L-I-M methodology developed by William O'Neil,which has proven highly successful. We set very strictrisk/reward guidelines and whittle the possibilities down to ahandful of companies with superior balance sheets and liquidity,and little or no debt. Then we take this short list andsubject it to a rigorous proprietary system based on cutting-edgecomputerized technical analysis. This incorporates both fundamental andtechnical factors like : � Valuation Indicators -- P/E Ratio, Relative P/E Ratio, Projected P/E Ratio, Price/Book Value Ratio, Price/Cash Flow Ratio, Price/Capital Spending Ratio, Price/Sales Ratio � Earnings Indicators -- Earnings Per Share, Earnings Growth Rate, Projected Earnings, Earnings Velocity, EPS Increase, EPS Consistency, Return on Assets, Return on Equity � Debt Risk Indicators -- Current Ratio, Debt/Equity Ratio, Interest Coverage, Debt Service/EPS � Balance Sheet Indicators -- Book Value Growth Rate, Capital Spending Growth Rate, Cash/Price Ratio, Inventory Turnover, Receivables Turnover, Asset Turnover � Volume Indicators -- Volume/Share, 30-Day Average Volume, Vol/30-Day Average Volume Ratio, 5-Day/30-Day Average Volume Ratio, Short Interest � Performance Indicators -- Relative Strength, Price Growth Rates, Least Squares Deviation, EPS Rank, Price Rank, Group Rank, Accumulation Distribution � Background Indicators -- Number and Percentage of Institutional Holdings, Number of Outstanding Shares, Market Capitalization, Insider Trading and Exercise of Options � Technical Indicators -- Moving Averages, MACD, Momentum, Stochastics, Wilder's RSI, Daily Range, High/Low, Beta, Volatility, McClellan Oscillator and many more � Forecasting Indicators -- Next 5 Weeks, Next 4 Months, Next 1 Year and Next 3 Year % Probability of Increase and % Gain I realize that's a staggering numberof factors to take into account. MASX 47.25 12/02/96 462 575 47.25 New Buy Centenial Technologies CTN 35.63 12/02/96 613 763 35.63 New Buy Zitel Inc. ZITL 22.88 12/02/96 954 1188 22.88 New Buy Paul Harris Stores PAUH 18.25 12/02/96 1197 1489 18.25 New Buy Tarrant Apparel Group TAGS 13.75 12/02/96 1977 13.75 New Buy Chips & Technologies CHPS 21.06 12/02/96 1290 21.06 New Buy Herley Industries HRLY 12.88 12/02/96 2112 12.88 New Buy US Air Group U 23.25 12/02/96 1169 23.25 New Buy 1995-96 Total Return : $150K Portfolio: 213.07% $250K Portfolio: 188.42% MARKETREVIEW For the last couple of months, while thelarge-cap stocks that make up the Dow Jones Industrial Average andS&P500 have been leading the market to all time highs, thesmall-cap stocks have been severely lagging. Although the Nasdaqcomposite has also gained substantially, most of this return hascome from large companies like Microsoft and Intel. So far in 1996, the smaller stock orientedRussell 2000 index has grown only 11.77%. The stocks recommendedin this newsletter closely resemble those in the Russell 2000.Since July 1, 1996, the Russell 2000 has grown only by 1.84%. But aren’tsmall stocks supposed to outperform their larger brethren? Over thelong-term the answer is an emphatic YES! In the shorter termhowever, markets are sometimes dominated by perceptions orchanges in investor sentiment. The word on the Street is that institutionalmoney managers have been bombarded with new cash flowing intomutual funds and they remain cautious as the bull marketcontinues. Looking for somewhere to put the new funds, they havesought shelter in the safer blue-chips. The subsequent increasein demand for these stocks has driven the large-caps higher andleft the small-caps behind. Despite their recent lackluster performance,the longer-term performance of small-cap is far superior to the large-caps.As things stand today, the small-cap stocks are now betterrelative values. The cyclical extremes of Wall Street sometimesdefy rationality, but over a period of time these disparitiesnormally fall back in line. Sooner or later, the correlation ofreturns between small-caps and large-caps will return to reasonable levels. For those investors who have the patience andthe stomach to weather the short-term volatile fluctuations of thissector, small-cap growth stocks continue to offer an opportunityto achieve superior long-term returns. BUSINESS SUMMARIES OF NEW STOCKS ADDED TO THE MODEL PORTFOLIO Innovex Inc. (NASD: INVX) develops and manufactures thin film lead wire assemblies for the disk drive industry. INVX also develops and manufactures peacemaker lead wires and other medical devices and software for document storage, retrieval and management. For the 9 months ended 6/96, sales rose 32% to $47M. Net income rose 38% to $9.3M. Revenues benefited from increased demand for lead wire assemblies. Earnings also reflect manufacturing efficiencies. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 22,529; after tax earnings were 3,851. (expressed in Thousands) Cymer, Inc. (NASD: CYMI) provides excimer laser illumination sources for use in deep ultraviolet photolithography systems targeted at the pilot and volume production segments of the semiconductor manufacturing market. For the 6 mos. ended 6/30/96, revenues rose from $7.3M to $19.2M. Net income totaled $957K vs. a loss of $383K. Results reflect a rise in the number of laser systems sold from 11 to 42 systems, and an increase in foreign currency exchange gains. UTI Energy Corp.(AMEX: UTI) provides onshore contract drilling services for companies engaged in the exploration & production of oil and natural gas. The Company also provides pressure pumping services. For the 6 mos. ended 6/30/96, revenues rose from $15M to $40.1M. Net income from cont. ops. totaled $1.7M vs. a loss of $613K. Results reflect incremental revenues from the 11/1/95 acquisition of FWA Drilling Co., Inc. and improved productivity. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 26,269; after tax earnings were 1,610. (expressed in Thousands) American Power Conversion (NASD: APCC) designs, develops, manufactures and markets a line of uninterruptible power supply products, electrical surge protection devices, power conditioning products and related software/accessories. For the 9 mos. ended 9/30/96, net sales rose 33% to $496.8M. Net income rose 18% to $62.2M. Results reflect strong worldwide demand for the Company's products, partially offset by lower margins due to a shift in product mix and higher manufacturing costs. MacDermid Inc. (NASD: MACD) develops, produces and markets a broad line of specialty chemical products for the metal & plastic finishing and electronics industries. MACD also markets chemical supplies and equipment produced by others. For the 3 months ended 6/96, sales rose 48% to $72.7M. Net income applic. to Common rose 54% to $4.5M. Results benefited from improvements in the imaging business. Results also reflect decreased S/G/A expenses as a percentage of sales. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 74,038; after tax earnings were 5,506. (expressed in Thousands) Market Facts, Inc. (NASD: MFAC) offers custom market research services for large corporate marketers. MFAC gathers information from surveys and through established databases. Revenues for the 9 months ended 9/96 rose 25% to $59.3M. Net income increased 53% to $2.3M. Results benefited from a significant expansion of major program services for existing as well as new clients. Results also reflect lower operating expenses as a percentage of revenues. Warrantec Corp. (NASD: WTEC), through its subsidiaries, markets & administers service contract programs to retailers, distributors & manufacturers of automobiles, recreational vehicles, automotive components, appliances, entertainment products, computers & communications equipment. For the 6 months ended 9/30/96, revenues rose 71% to $74M. Net income rose from $1.3M to $3.4M. Results reflect higher volumes from new and existing clients & a $1.9M gain on sale of the equity joint venture. Tripos Inc. (NASD: TRPS) delivers science, tools and analysis services that advance customers' creativity and productivity in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and biotechnology industries. TRPS also is a reseller of third-party hardware products. For the 6 mos. ended 6/30/96, revenues rose 29% to $11.6M. Net income totaled $173K vs. a loss of $300K. Results reflect the addition of accelerated discovery services sales (a new product line), and a rise in hardware sales. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 7,553; after tax earnings were 688. (expressed in Thousands) Marine Drilling Companies (NASD: MDCO) is engaged in the contract drilling of oil and gas wells for independent and major oil and gas companies. For the nine months ended 9/96, revenues increased 97% to $78.4M. Net income totaled $13.3M vs. a loss of $5.6M. Revenues benefited from increased average day rates, a higher number of marketed rigs and increased utilization of marketed rigs. Earnings also reflect lower operating expenses as a percentage of revenue. Herbalife International (NASD: HERB) distributes and markets weight-control products, health and nutritional supplements, and skin and personal care products. HERB operates in 32 countries in the Americas, Europe and Asia. For the 6 mos. ended 6/96, net sales rose 20% to $296.5M. Net income rose 37% to $19.6M. Results benefited from higher sales in Asia/Pacific Rim and The Americas. Earnings also reflect lower selling costs due to a revised format of sales events. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 160,741; after tax earnings were 11,339. (expressed in Thousands) Cliffs Drilling Company (NASD: CLDR) engages in contract drilling, primarily on a turnkey basis, of offshore oil and gas wells. CLDR also participates in oil/gas exploration and production activities. Revenues for the six months ended 6/30/96 increased 52% to $42.9M. Net income applicable to Common Stock totaled $5.7M vs. a loss of $995K. Results benefited from increased contributions from the engineering services business segment. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 43,497; after tax earnings were 4,309. (expressed in Thousands) MasTec Inc. (NASD: MASX) provides construction services to the telecommunications industry. MASX installs and maintains aerial, underground and buried copper and fiber optic cable, manhole systems, conduit and related services for telephone, CATV, utility & non utility customers. For the six months ended 6/96, revenues totaled $171.2M, up from $73.8M. Net income from cont. ops. rose 46% to $10.1M. Results reflect the expansion into new areas & gains from construction services. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 142,394; after tax earnings were 9,362. (expressed in Thousands) Centennial Technologies, Inc. (NYSE: CTN) designs, manufactures and markets PC cards, which are a credit card sized device inserted into a dedicated slot in a broad range of electronic equipment that contain microprocessors. For the FY ended 6/96, sales totaled $37.8M, up from $12.4M. Net income totaled $4.9M, up from $874K. Revenues benefited from an increase in volume of sales of PC cards. Earnings reflect lower S/G/A and R&D costs, as a percentage of sales. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 19,536; after tax earnings were 2,445. (expressed in Thousands) Zitel Inc. (NASD: ZITL) designs, manufactures and markets high performance, mission-critical storage subsystems for relational database, batch and on-line transaction processing. Total revenue for the nine months ended 6/30/96 decreased 7% to $18.4M. Net income decreased 54% to $3.8M. Revenues reflect lower royalty revenues and the discontinuance of the Company's OEM HiPPI interface card products. Earnings also reflect higher development spending and personnel. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 4,649; after tax earnings were 276. (expressed in Thousands) Paul Harris Stores, Inc. (NASD: PAUH) is a 235-store specialty retailer which offers moderately priced casual attire for career women. The Company's stores operate under various trademarks such as Paul Harris and Pasta. For the twenty-six weeks ended 8/3/96, net sales increased 7% to $76.4M. Net income totaled $202K vs. a loss of $2M. Revenues reflect an increase in comparable store sales. Earnings also reflect a decreased interest expense. For the quarter ended OCT 1996, revenues were 45,413; after tax earnings were 1,821. (expressed in Thousands) Tarrant Apparel Group (NASD: TAGS) designs and contracts the manufacture of and selling of moderately priced women apparel. TAGS serves both specialty retail and mass merchandise store chains. For the nine months ended 9/30/96, revenues remained flat at $161M. Net income (vs. pro forma) increased 20% to $7.3M. Revenues reflect increased sales to the Target divisions, offset by decreased sales to Kmart. Earnings reflect a reduction of sourcing for manufacturers. Chips & Technologies, Inc. (NASD: CHPS) is a supplier of highly integrated semiconductor and software solutions to personal computer manufacturers. For the 3 months ended 9/30/96, net sales rose 20% to $44.5M. Net income totaled $9.5M, up from $4.4M. Results benefited from increases in unit shipments of portable graphics accelerators. Earnings also reflect an improved mix of products including higher margin portable graphics accelerators and declining wafer costs. Herley Industries (NASD: HRLY) manufactures flight instrumentation products, encompassing transponder products and command and control systems; and microwave products including microwave integrated circuits, receiver-protectors, and magentrons. For the FY ended 7/28/96, net sales increased 19% to $29M. Net income totaled $3.7M vs. a loss of $4.9M. Results benefited from increased sales of flight instrumentation products & the absence of a $5.4M charge for legal actions. For the quarter ended OCT 1996, revenues were 7,508; after tax earnings were 872. (expressed in Thousands) US Air Group (NYSE: U) is the parent company of USAir Inc., which is an air carrier engaged primarily in the business of transporting passengers, property and mail. Revenues for the six months ended 6/96 increased 7% to $4.02B. Net income applic. to Common totaled $123.7M vs. a loss of $25.7M. Revenues reflect higher passenger volumes and a higher per-passenger fee structure. Earnings reflect a lower interest expense and fewer owned aircraft in USAir's fleet. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 2,072,567; after tax earnings were 67,738. (expressed in Thousands) Applied Magnetics (NYSE: APM) is an independent supplier of magnetic recording heads and of head stack assemblies for rigid disk drives. For the 9 months ended 6/29/96, net sales rose 28% to $255.5M. Net income totaled $20.1M vs. A loss of $7.7M. Results benefited from increased sales of thin film disk heads due to continued volume production on qualified customer programs. Results also reflect higher gross margins due to production process improvements. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 89,302; after tax earnings were 12,144. (expressed in Thousands) ENSCO International (NYSE: ESV) explores, develops & produces oil & gas both onshore & offshore, & provides marine transportation services. Revenues for the 9 mos. ended 9/96 rose 62% to $316.4M. Net income from cont. ops. applic. to Common rose from $24.7M to $63.5M. Revenues reflect improved North Sea and Gulf of Mexico average day rates, and the return of 3 jack-up rigs. Earnings reflect utilization of supply vessels and a $6.4M gain from the settlement w/TransAmerica Natural Gas Corp. GenRad, Inc. (NYSE: GEN) is a supplier of integrated test, measurement and diagnostic solutions for the manufacture and maintenance of electronic products. Revenues for the nine months ended 9/28/96 increased 15% to $134.9M. Net income increased 95% to $17.7M. Revenues reflect increased orders due to the acquisition of TTA and strong demand in all aspects of the business. Earnings also reflect continued improvements in manufacturing costs and efficiencies. Lattice Semiconductor (NASD: LSCC) designs, develops and markets high performance programmable logic devices (PLDs) & related development system software. Revenues for the 3 mos. ended 6/29/96 rose 7% to $48.2M. Net income rose 18% to $10.4M. Revenues benefited from new product sales, primarily in the high-density segment of the PLD market. Net income also reflects improved capacity utilization, other reduced manufacturing costs, and increased cash & investment balances. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 48,638; after tax earnings were 10,460. (expressed in Thousands) Clayton Williams (NASD: CWEI) is engaged in the exploration for, development, and production of oil and natural gas in South and East Texas, Southeastern New Mexico and the Texas Gulf Coast. Revenues for the 6 months ended 6/96 rose 9% to $29.5M. Net income totaled $3.8M vs. a loss of $1.5M. Revenues reflect higher oil prices and production, and increased gas prices. Earnings reflect lower production levels (on a BOE basis) and higher proved reserves from new wells. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 15,584; after tax earnings were 3,470. (expressed in Thousands) Zygo Corp. (NASD: ZIGO) designs, develops, manufactures and markets high performance, non-contact electro-optical measuring instruments and systems. Zygo also manufactures precision optical components. Revenues for the FY ended 6/96 rose 66% to $53.5M. Earnings totaled $7.9M, up from $2.7M. Results reflect more demand for electro-optical instruments and accessories. Earnings also reflect volume-related manufacturing efficiencies and increased interest income. For the quarter ended SEP 1996, revenues were 18,443; after tax earnings were 3,100. (expressed in Thousands) Clarify Inc. (NASD: CLFY) develops, markets, and supports adaptable client/server application software designed to address the external and internal service needs of today's global enterprises. For the nine months ended 9/30/96, revenues rose from $16.7M to $37.1M. Net income increased from $890K to $5.3M. Results benefited from increased market acceptance of existing products and the expansion of the sales force. The Mutual FundBulletin features four model portfolios. These are : 1. INDEX FUNDS PORTFOLIO 3. FIDELITY GROWTH PORTFOLIO 2. NO-LOAD GROWTH PORTFOLIO 4. FIDELITY SECTOR PORTFOLIO The INDEXFUNDS PORTFOLIO uses the Rydex Family ofFunds (1-800-820-0888). By using these funds (Nova, OTC and Ursa)you can go both long and short depending on market conditions. Rydex Nova is an S&P500 index fund with a beta of 1.5. Thismeans when you invest in the Nova fund and it goes up, you make50% more than the S&P500 index itself. Rydex OTCis an index fund that tracks the NASDAQ index. The combination ofRydex Nova and OTC, lets us participate in both the large and thesmall-cap stocks. Rydex is only family that offers a fund that isshort the S&P500. This makes Rydex Ursa a rather uniquefund. It goes up when theS&P500 goes down and vice-versa. Thismeans you make money as the S&P500 goes down. If you are ableto find other similar funds, you may be able to substitute them forthe Rydex funds. Jack White and Company offers all three Rydexfunds while Charles Schwab offers only the Nova fund. The NO-LOADGROWTH PORTFOLIO consists of no-load fundsthat can be bought and sold through Charles Schwab & Company(1-800-2-NO-LOAD), Jack White & Company (1-800-233-3411) orFidelity FundsNetwork (1-800-544-7777). MAGNIFICENT MARKET TIMING Market timing has been the one, forever, secretof investment success. In all markets. In all times. All investmentshave their cycles, periods when prices rise and periods when theyfall. The idea is to buy before pricesrise and to sell before prices fall. Opportunities abound. But only if you buy andif you sell at the right time. This is where we come in ... the Mutual Fund Bulletin specializes in stock market timing! We tell you what,as well as when, to buy and sell. Studies have shown that for a typical stock orequity fund, 60% of the price movement can be directly attributedto the movement of the overall market. Therefore, it is extremelyimportant to stay on the right side of the overall market trend. Itis important to know the current phase of the market, and when itis ready to change direction. Vital Information's Best Intermediate-Term TimingSystem (BITS) provides a disciplined, objective andscientific approach to timing the market, freeof bias and emotion. It uses an arsenal of the finest stockmarket indicators available, organized into a complex set ofrules, to automatically signal stock market tops and bottoms. BITS is based on a mathematical model thatautomatically locates situations that have historically predictedstock market moves resulting in excellent buying and sellingopportunities. It has an excellent trackrecord of accurately signaling market turns.We never predict. Instead we follow the trend of the market. Weprefer to be prepared, so that when a market comes along, we cansimply sidestep it. Frequently, you read in the financial press theopinion that timing doesn't work. This myth is perpetuated bythose who have failed to develop a sound timing system. If youwere to study the long-term charts of stock market prices, you woulddiscover that the market moves up and down in trends, over aperiod of months, or even years. You are the best. I am a new subscriber andI’m excited. The calls you’ve made this year are nextto being clairvoyant. The market is down today, big time, andI’m not just out but in Ursa. What a thrill. You are the best.Keep up the great work. – A. Murray Even though the market moves sideways at times,this motion is always temporary. Most of the time, the market isin the process of going up, or it is in the process of goingdown. The Mutual Fund Bulletin's plan follows the trend of the market,capturing the biggest part of any uptrend, and dodging thebiggest part of any downtrend. When we dodge the downtrends, we dodge bear markets. Any downtrend has the potential to turn into a seriousbear market. The reason we make more money than buy-and-holdinvestors is because we don't have to make up for bear marketlosses when the market starts advancing again. If you are a buy-and-hold investor, you'llcapture the advances but you won't necessarily profit from them,since you'll be making up for your bear market losses. Forexample, buy-and-hold investors who captured 1991's big advance merelymade up losses from 1990's big decline. Even more chilling, consider the bear market of1973-74. If you had invested $10,000 in a stock index fund onJanuary 2, 1973, your investment would have shrunk to $5,180 overthe next 21 months -- a 48.20% decline. After this loss, youwould have had to hold your investment more than seven and a halfyears just to make up your losses and break-even with yourinitial $10,000 investment. The important thing to understand is thatmarket advances are for getting your money to grow, not for makingup past losses. The key isknowing the trend of the market, so thatyou can dodge the bear markets and capture the advances thatfollow them. The Mutual Fund Bulletin will clearly showyou whether the intermediate-term trend of the market is up ordown and whether you should be long or in cash. If you had followed this system from 7/1/63 to10/31/96, a mutual fund that closely tracks the NASDAQ index, you wouldhave made a 25.14%annualized return. This performancebeats all others and has outperformed the popular buy-and-holdapproach to stock fund investing. One question we are often asked is, "How did your market timing modeldo during the crash of 1987?". You'dnotice that BITS not only side-stepped the crash of 1987, butalso the mini crash of 1989 and the market decline of 1990. Thenit signaled the powerful upmove of 1991. Consider the performance of BITS in recentyears. On 10/07/92, BITS identified a strong market uptrend andwe switched from the safety of money-market funds into stockfunds. While thousands of investors sat waiting on the sidelinesuntil the market climbed higher, we got into the market quickly andsaw our funds steadily generate profits. In contrast, manyinvestors were still entering the already overvalued market aslate as February 1994. Before the market corrected sharply in March 1994, our systemidentified a new downtrend and we switched back to the safety ofmoney market funds. In December 1994, many investors were too jitteryto invest in the stocks market, fearing another down move. However, BITS gave us a buy signal on December27, 1994 and we got invested in stock funds. Guess what? While ourportfolios are up over 40% in 1995, the other investors missedanother big advance. Buy-and-hold investors, of course, aremaking up for their 1994 losses. We, on the other hand, made 67.56% for our readers in 1995-96. The reason our system works better thanbuy-and-hold (and pray!) is that it mechanically identifies the trends.As a result, you know when to be in the market and when to beout. No other piece of information is more important. Our research shows that investing in equitiesduring market uptrends, then switching to money funds duringmarket downtrends, could safely produce 20-25% annualizedcompounded growth. Today we can say that anyone committing to ourplan for two years or more dramatically reduces stock market risk. Bear markets are inevitable, like death andtaxes. Sooner or later a major one will strike, cutting the portfoliovalues of buy-and-hold investors into half. But, by using the signals from BITS, youwill be able to get out in time - for maximumprofits! That's because BITSpresages all new bull and bear markets, allowing you to get intothe market at major bottoms, and exit the market right at the top beforethe downturn starts. And you never have to worry about surpriseshifts in the market robbing you of your profits, because BITS is specificallydesigned to give you a wide margin of advance notice whenever the marketis ready to turn. How SuccessfulHas It Been? Judge For Yourself... Historical BITS Data ANALYSIS SUMMARY Start Date: 07/01/63 Start OTC Value: 33.63 End Date: 10/31/96 End OTC Value: 1221.51 OTC Gain: +3532.20% Annualized OTC Gain +11.50% BITS Gain: +163830% Annualized BITS Gain: +25.14% Total Trades: 52 % Winning Trades: 80% Largest Gain: +94.1% Largest Gain: +94.1% Following the above signals and investing in amutual fund that closely tracks the NASDAQ index (for example the RydexOTC Fund) would have turneda one-time investment of $1000 into $1,639,304. The same $1000 invested using a buy & hold approachwould have yielded $36,322. Past performance, of course,is no guarantee of future results. The period 1963 to 1988 shows hypothetical resultsfrom computer backtesting of our market timing models. The timingsystem has been in real-time use since November 1988. BITS was developed in late 1988 and was testedon historical data from 1963 to 1988. The Nasdaq and theS&P500 index were used to generate the buy/sell signals andcompute the returns. Since 1989, BITS has been in use real-time andit has proven itself in both backtesting and actual trading. Onaverage it signals a trade every 7 months. The accuracy rating is80%, with every 4 out of 5 winning trades. The compoundedannualized return is 25.14% per year. There are a number of reasons why we areusing the Rydex family of funds for trading BITS signals. Rydex Nova is an S&P500 index fund with a beta of 1.5. Thismeans when BITS is correct in its long signal, you make 50% morethan the S&P500 index itself. Rydex OTC is the only indexfund that tracks the Nasdaq index. The combination of Rydex Novaand OTC when BITS is long, lets us participate in both the largeand the small-cap stocks. Rydex is only family that offers a fundthat is short the S&P500. This makes Rydex Ursaa rather unique fund. It goes up when the S&P500 goes downand vice-versa. This means when BITS is correct in its cash/shortsignal you make money as the S&P500 goes down. THE AMAZINGPOWER OF COMPOUNDING Long-term compounding is your single mostpowerful wealth building tool, and its free. But to make it work,you've got to keep your money growing. That's why it is soimportant to get out of the market during the downtrends. Over time, compounding converts smallamounts of money into enormous sums. For instance, if you invested$4,000 a year (the amount you and your spouse could put into twoIRAs) in an investment earning 20%, in ten years your money wouldgrow to $128,601. After 20 years, your investment would be worth$900,102. And get ready, because in 25 years, you'd have a whopping $2,269,509! With long-term compounding, you don't have todo anything fancy. You don't have to take unnecessary risks. The wholeidea is not to interfere with compounding. Just make steady gainsand let compounding work its magic! However, compounding takes time, and if youdon't have a simple and safe plan, you won't feel comfortableinvesting your serious money over the long term. What's more, ifyour plan does not put you safely on the sidelines during bear markets,you'll lose money and ruin the good work compounding has startedfor you. Let me now tell you how our investment planworks. Once you see how simple it is -- how it keeps your money growing-- you'll understand why Mutual Fund Bulletin subscribers areable to commit their money and stick with it over the long term. HERE'S HOWOUR INVESTMENT PLAN WORKS The BITS market timing system was created outof hard facts. It is a scientific system that has proven itsvalidity after decades of testing and investing. It does onething and one thing only, and it does this one thing very well: it identifies markettrends. The system has just two trading rules: one forbuying and one for selling. There are no gray areas. We use acomplex mathematical formula. We apply our formula to the majormarket averages and other stock market statistics like new highsand new lows. This reveals the trend of the market. An uptrend isa buy signal, and a downtrend is a sell signal. That's all thereis to it. We use mutual funds as our investment vehicles.I am sure I don't have to explain the merits of mutual funds.Today, nearly everybody knows that mutual funds are superior inevery way: management, performance, safety, costs, and tradingconvenience. We profit from the uptrends byinvesting in growth funds, but during the downtrends we protectour profits by switching to money market funds. As soon as the downtrend is over, and a new uptrend begins,we switch back to growth funds. Our trading is easily handledover the phone with just a few calls per year. Once you start reading the Mutual FundBulletin, you'll always know the trend of the market, and what actionto take for both profit and safety. Since 1963, our market timingsystem (BITS) has identified every major trend in the market. Duringthis time, we moved in and out of the market on average every 7months. We never labored over a buy decision. We neverlabored over a sell decision. We never lost any sleep. We always knewwhat to do. Deciding when to buy and sell is the most agonizingpart of investing. It can be emotionally wrenching. But our investment plan completelyeliminates emotional decision-making. It mechanically providesbuy and sell signals, and that makes it near fool-proof. I have never seen a simpler, safer, or morecomfortable way to keep your money growing and compounding. And once you see how easy it is to makemoney this way (by following the trends), you will no longer carewhy the market goes up or down. The marketalways goes up or down, and its a good thing it does, becausethat's how we keep making money. Time and again we hear from subscribers whoseonly regret is that they did not find us sooner. Newcomers, ofcourse, are always skeptical. The plan does seem too good to betrue. But as you can see from the trades on page 7-9, the planworks. In fact it works like crazy. Plain andsimple. No wonder it has an average yearly return of almost 25% overthe last 33 years. Now you know how our simple investment planworks. And, I think you can see how it can work for you. All youneed are 10 minutes a month and a desire to simplify and enrichyour life. HOW TO FOLLOWOUR INVESTMENT PLAN? And you willstay invested only as long as the uptrend continues. When theuptrend is broken and turns down, you'll call your mutual fundcompany and switch to the safety of their money market fund We will tell you which mutualfunds to use. Not only do we analyze their past performance, but alsoevaluate the likelihood of superior future performance by weighingall available fundamental and technical information. The top performing funds in any given periodalways outperform the market averages. Even when the market as a whole isgoing down, some funds make huge gains. But fund leadership isconstantly changing. It means you don't have to constantlywatch and worry about timing your investments. Successful fund investing means sticking withthe winners only when the trend is upwards; not buying andholding (and praying!). The drawback of a "buy & hold"approach is that in down markets your fund may lose as much as 50%of its value. At that point it would have to gain at least 100%just to break even. And that might take a long, long time. Onething is quite clear : you'll make more money by side-stepping market corrections. We rely on a rational, disciplined approach.When the market begins to advance, our indicators generate a buysignal, prompting a move into stock funds. They also flag thedownturns and generate a sell signal, so we're safely in money marketfunds. Steady, consistentgrowth is the hallmark of our safe and methodical approach. We are systematic about following trends thatpay off with significant gains in the long run. There's no guesswork.We don't try to predict the next move in the market at random.Instead we focus on detecting trends and reacting appropriately.The system of switching between top-ranked stock funds and moneymarket funds provides the flexibility needed to respond tochanging market conditions. In 1995-96 our Fidelity Sector Portfolio is upan astounding 79.66%. Compare that to the performance of the major averagesor any other investment publication, and you'll agree that the HotFunds Analyststands head and shoulders above the crowd.The Hot Funds Analyst features fourmodel portfolios. These are : 1. INDEX FUNDS PORTFOLIO 3. FIDELITY GROWTH PORTFOLIO 2. NO-LOAD GROWTH PORTFOLIO 4. FIDELITY SECTOR PORTFOLIO The INDEXFUNDS PORTFOLIO uses the Rydex Family ofFunds (1-800-820-0888). By using these funds (Nova, OTC and Ursa)you can go both long and short depending on market conditions. Rydex Nova is an S&P500 index fund with a beta of 1.5. Thismeans when you invest in the Nova fund and it goes up, you make50% more than the S&P500 index itself. Rydex OTCis an index fund that tracks the NASDAQ index. The combination ofRydex Nova and OTC, lets us participate in both the large and thesmall-cap stocks. Rydex is only family that offers a fund that isshort the S&P500. This makes Rydex Ursa a rather uniquefund. It goes up when theS&P500 goes down and vice-versa. Thismeans you make money as the S&P500 goes down. MAGNIFICENT MARKET TIMING Market timing has been the one, forever, secretof investment success. In all markets. In all times. All investmentshave their cycles, periods when prices rise and periods when theyfall. The idea is to buy before pricesrise and to sell before prices fall. Opportunities abound. But only if you buy andif you sell at the right time. This is where we come in ... the HotFunds Analystspecializes in stock market timing! Wetell you what, as well as when, to buy and sell. Studies have shown that for a typical stock orequity fund, 60% of the price movement can be directly attributedto the movement of the overall market. Therefore, it is extremelyimportant to stay on the right side of the overall market trend. Itis important to know the current phase of the market, and when itis ready to change direction. Vital Information's Best Intermediate-Term TimingSystem (BITS) provides a disciplined, objective andscientific approach to timing the market, freeof bias and emotion. It uses an arsenal of the finest stockmarket indicators available, organized into a complex set ofrules, to automatically signal stock market tops and bottoms. BITS is based on a mathematical model thatautomatically locates situations that have historically predictedstock market moves resulting in excellent buying and sellingopportunities. It has an excellent trackrecord of accurately signaling market turns.We never predict. Instead we follow the trend of the market. Weprefer to be prepared, so that when a market comes along, we cansimply sidestep it. Frequently, you read in the financial press theopinion that timing doesn't work. This myth is perpetuated bythose who have failed to develop a sound timing system. If youwere to study the long-term charts of stock market prices, you woulddiscover that the market moves up and down in trends, over aperiod of months, or even years. You are the best. I am a new subscriber andI’m excited. The calls you’ve made this year are nextto being clairvoyant. The market is down today, big time, andI’m not just out but in Ursa. What a thrill. You are the best.Keep up the great work. – A. Murray Even though the market moves sideways at times,this motion is always temporary. Most of the time, the market isin the process of going up, or it is in the process of goingdown. The Hot Funds Analyst's plan follows the trend of the market,capturing the biggest part of any uptrend, and dodging thebiggest part of any downtrend. When we dodge the downtrends, we dodge bear markets. Any downtrend has the potential to turn into a seriousbear market. The reason we make more money than buy-and-holdinvestors is because we don't have to make up for bear marketlosses when the market starts advancing again. If you are a buy-and-hold investor, you'llcapture the advances but you won't necessarily profit from them,since you'll be making up for your bear market losses. Forexample, buy-and-hold investors who captured 1991's big advance merelymade up losses from 1990's big decline. Even more chilling, consider the bear market of1973-74. If you had invested $10,000 in a stock index fund onJanuary 2, 1973, your investment would have shrunk to $5,180 overthe next 21 months -- a 48.20% decline. After this loss, youwould have had to hold your investment more than seven and a halfyears just to make up your losses and break-even with yourinitial $10,000 investment. The important thing to understand is thatmarket advances are for getting your money to grow, not for makingup past losses. The key isknowing the trend of the market, so thatyou can dodge the bear markets and capture the advances thatfollow them. The Hot Funds Analystwill clearly show you whether the intermediate-term trend of themarket is up or down and whether you should be long or in cash. If you had followed this system from 7/1/63 to10/31/96, a mutual fund that closely tracks the NASDAQ index, you wouldhave made a 25.14%annualized return. This performancebeats all others and has outperformed the popular buy-and-holdapproach to stock fund investing. One question we are often asked is, "How did your market timing modeldo during the crash of 1987?". You'dnotice that BITS not only side-stepped the crash of 1987, butalso the mini crash of 1989 and the market decline of 1990. Thenit signaled the powerful upmove of 1991. Consider the performance of BITS in recentyears. On 10/07/92, BITS identified a strong market uptrend andwe switched from the safety of money-market funds into stockfunds. While thousands of investors sat waiting on the sidelinesuntil the market climbed higher, we got into the market quickly andsaw our funds steadily generate profits. In contrast, manyinvestors were still entering the already overvalued market aslate as February 1994. Before the market corrected sharply in March 1994, our systemidentified a new downtrend and we switched back to the safety ofmoney market funds. In December 1994, many investors were too jitteryto invest in the stocks market, fearing another down move. However, BITS gave us a buy signal on December27, 1994 and we got invested in stock funds. Guess what? While ourportfolios are up over 40% in 1995, the other investors missedanother big advance. Buy-and-hold investors, of course, aremaking up for their 1994 losses. We, on the other hand, made 67.56% for our readers in 1995-96. The reason our system works better thanbuy-and-hold (and pray!) is that it mechanically identifies the trends.As a result, you know when to be in the market and when to beout. No other piece of information is more important. Our research shows that investing in equitiesduring market uptrends, then switching to money funds duringmarket downtrends, could safely produce 20-25% annualizedcompounded growth. Today we can say that anyone committing to ourplan for two years or more dramatically reduces stock market risk. Bear markets are inevitable, like death andtaxes. Sooner or later a major one will strike, cutting the portfoliovalues of buy-and-hold investors into half. But, by using the signals from BITS, youwill be able to get out in time - for maximumprofits! That's because BITSpresages all new bull and bear markets, allowing you to get intothe market at major bottoms, and exit the market right at the top beforethe downturn starts. And you never have to worry about surpriseshifts in the market robbing you of your profits, because BITS is specificallydesigned to give you a wide margin of advance notice whenever the marketis ready to turn. Thismeans when BITS is correct in its long signal, you make 50% morethan the S&P500 index itself. Rydex OTC is the only indexfund that tracks the Nasdaq index. The combination of Rydex Novaand OTC when BITS is long, lets us participate in both the largeand the small-cap stocks. Rydex is only family that offers a fundthat is short the S&P500. This makes Rydex Ursaa rather unique fund. It goes up when the S&P500 goes downand vice-versa. This means when BITS is correct in its cash/shortsignal you make money as the S&P500 goes down. THE AMAZINGPOWER OF COMPOUNDING Long-term compounding is your single mostpowerful wealth building tool, and its free. But to make it work,you've got to keep your money growing. That's why it is soimportant to get out of the market during the downtrends. Over time, compounding converts smallamounts of money into enormous sums. For instance, if you invested$4,000 a year (the amount you and your spouse could put into twoIRAs) in an investment earning 20%, in ten years your money wouldgrow to $128,601. After 20 years, your investment would be worth$900,102. And get ready, because in 25 years, you'd have a whopping $2,269,509! With long-term compounding, you don't have todo anything fancy. You don't have to take unnecessary risks. The wholeidea is not to interfere with compounding. Just make steady gainsand let compounding work its magic! However, compounding takes time, and if youdon't have a simple and safe plan, you won't feel comfortableinvesting your serious money over the long term. What's more, ifyour plan does not put you safely on the sidelines during bear markets,you'll lose money and ruin the good work compounding has startedfor you. Let me now tell you how our investment planworks. Once you see how simple it is -- how it keeps your money growing-- you'll understand why Hot Funds Analystsubscribers are able to commit their money and stick with it over thelong term. There are no gray areas. We use acomplex mathematical formula. We apply our formula to the majormarket averages and other stock market statistics like new highsand new lows. This reveals the trend of the market. An uptrend isa buy signal, and a downtrend is a sell signal. That's all thereis to it. We use mutual funds as our investment vehicles.I am sure I don't have to explain the merits of mutual funds.Today, nearly everybody knows that mutual funds are superior inevery way: management, performance, safety, costs, and tradingconvenience. Created and Developed by: Multimedia Marketing Group Inc Comments to Webmaster © Copyright 1995, 1996 All Rights ReservedWT03-B27-19IA089-000953-B048-11http://www.pjp.com:80/pro.html 198.5.254.122 19970208041050 text/html 5868HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:10:28 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 05:18:18 GMTContent-length: 5692 Fred Meyer Challenge - #1 Non-PGA TOUR Golf Event Ask the Pros We were able to visit with most of the Challenge players over the past three days and ask them to respond to your great comments and questions. We aren't able to answer all of them because of the huge number we received, but we are able to post many of them here. Jack Nicklaus From Steve Hammer: I collect Ping and other putters. I would like to know what is your all time favorite putter? At this stage of my career, my favorite putter is the one that's working today. From Bob Lewis Why don't you play more often on the Senior Tour? The Senior Tour is terrific for most of the guys, but the courses are set up short in order to accomodate everyone. That, combined with soft greens, makes the courses play easy which I have never played well, because my strong suit was never my short game. My strengths have always been course management and the long game. Peter Jacobsen From Brad Niles: No question -- just wanted to wish you and the other members of the Ryder Cup team the best of luck. Bring it home! Thanks for the encouragement, Brad. I think we have a great team this year. From Sharon Moore Are there any plans to bring a PGA Tour event to Portland? The PGA offered us a tour event this year opposite the World Series of Golf, but we felt we just didn't have time to prepare properly. We would need two years to plan properly. It's something we continue to look at and evaluate, but we're having an awful lot of fun with The Challenge right now. Steve Elkington From: Michael Tollin: How do you hit a 7-iron 202 yards? Strong lofts, or are you really that strong? How far do pros hit an average 7-iron with off the shelf lofts? It depends on many factors, such as wind, slope, lie, elevation and probably most of all, adrenaline. All things being equal, most pros hit a 7-iron about 170-180. Ben Crenshaw From: Doug Johnson: What is the best way to practice at the range -- with one club per session, or with multiple clubs? I like to start with the short clubs and work my way through the bag to the driver. And then finish with a few more pitch shots. Fred Couples From: Jack and Mary Dare Tell us the truth, Freddie, how is your back? It feels good and isn't giving me any problems right now. My problem is that I'm a little rusty so I plan to play in 3 out of the next 4 tour events between now and the Ryder Cup. Ernie Els From: James Lowry Do you have a diagonal move forward initiating the down swing, or do you keep your spine centered and rotate your left hip around it? I don't use my legs quite as much as some of the players out here, and my forward move tends to be more of a turn than a slide. From: Will Przybylek How does it feel to be the best young player on the PGA Tour? I have faults in my swing like anyone else. I'm trying to get my game more under control. I feel like I'm maturing a little bit, and I've enjoyed being in contention the past few weeks. Phil Mickelson From: Bill Phillips Are you a natural lefty? Did anyone ever try to get you to play golf right-handed? Actually, I do everything right-handed. I started playing golf left-handed because I would watch my father practice in the back yard. I would stand facing him to get an image of his swing, and I would swing along with him. To do that, I was swinging left-janded. Payne Stewart From: Les Taylor What are the reasons that professional golfers can hit the ball consistently farther than I can? I hit the ball pretty well, but I can't get the distance I see the professionals hitting it. Is the balls you use, the clubs, or your swing? We all have access to the same equipment in terms of balls and clubs -- the main reason the players out here are so long is technique and timing. Distance comes from clubhead speed and clubhead speed comes from a delayed hit, versus hitting it from the top as so many amateur players do. Brian Henninger From: Patrick Keane I recently read John Feinstein's book on the PGA Tour, "A Good Walk Spoiled", and I felt that your feature was the most compelling and interesting. I wish you all the luck in the world on the tour. CYCLE OREGON VIII SEPTEMBER 10 - 16, 1995 Legs may quiver. Hearts may pound. Lungs may wheeze. But in the end, it's all worth it. No other ride offers the adventure, the thrill of the breathtaking scenery of Cycle Oregon. Seven days. Five hundred miles. Countless memories. Join us for a virtual tour along the route of Cycle Oregon 1995. Neil Mishalov Recaps This Years Ride Neil Mishalov, a participant in Cycle Oregon VIII, provides us with a recap of this years ride. Many feel this was the best Cycle Oregon ever. Welcome from Jonathan Nicholas Jonathan Nicholas, Oregonian columnist and President of Cycle Oregon, welcomes you and captures the essence of this years ride. 1995 Cycle Oregon Tourbook Elevation maps, mileage and description of each days ride (and menus). Message Board Post and read messages here. Curt Simkin's "Cycle for Life" Curt Simkins doubles up on Cycle Oregon in his fund raiser for the American Cancer Society. Give Us Your Input We've had great input regarding what you would like to see included here. There's still time for additions so let us know what you would like to see here. WELCOME FROM JONATHAN NICHOLAS PRESIDENT OF CYCLE OREGON The man the world came to know as Chief Joseph, leader in the nineteenth century of the people called the Nez Perce by the wandering French trappers, was a remarkable individual. He led his nomadic people in a life lived in rhythmic harmony with a landscape as wild, as rugged and as breathtaking as any on our planet. When he first came into contact with what Indians called the "endless village" of whites, Joseph urged upon his people a simple admonition: "Be brave and always tell the truth." Truth be told, few of the first U.S. government representatives to enter the Wallowa Valley were big on either valor or veracity. Little of the Nez Perce presence remains in this area today. But their spirit, and their legacy, haunts this spellbinding swath of canyon and rimrock, of snow and desert, of prairie and streams that sing. I'm delighted you have decided to join us on a remarkable bicycle ride, a journey through the heart of the American West. The country you are about to encounter is vast with promise, redolent with myth and memory, teasing yet with its potential as the native home of hope. As Oregon moves beyond boom-and-bust cycles, it may yet find here in its Northeastern corner a sustainable economy, what Oregonian historian Terence O'Donnell calls "that balance so rare." Please treat this land, and the people who carve a living from its bounty, with respect as they welcome us to the place we call wonderful, the place they call home. CYCLE OREGON VIII RECAP Neil Mishalov THE FACTS First things first. Here are some statistics about the ride. 	Number of Riders:		2,200	Registration Fee: 		$435	Riders from Oregon:		1,514	Riders from California:		265	# States Represented:		38	Oldest Rider:			78 Years	Youngest Rider:			9 Years	Female Riders:			623	Male Riders:			1,577	Days on the road:		Seven	Distance Cycled:		440 Miles	Total Elevation Gain:		27,300 Feet Weather: Sunny, no rain and temperatures in the 90�s during the day and 40�s at night Area Cycled: Wallowa Mountains, Strawberry Mountains, Blue Mountains, Hells Canyon National Recreation Area and the high desert. Towns Where We Camped: Athena, Elgin, Joseph, Halfway, Sumpter, Prairie City, Monument and Fossil. TEST: See if you can find these towns on your Oregon road map! THE LOGISTICS OK, now that the statistics are out of the way, I can tell you a little something about the trip. 1995 was the eighth year that Cycle Oregon took place, and it was the third year that I participated in the event. The ride is fully subscribed within a week of the applications being sent out, and each year the ride traverses a different route. This year we cycled through rural northeastern Oregon. Most of the towns that we cycled through or camped at have a population of less that 500 people. The trip traversed through the former home terrain of Chief Joseph and the Nez Perce Indians, former gold mining areas, the Oregon emigrant trail, hay fields and hills, hills, and more hills! An amazing thing about Cycle Oregon is how smoothly everything works. The logistics are impressive when you consider that there are 2,200 cyclists on the road, a couple of hundred support people, and many support vehicles. In addition, the riders were provided with three meals a day. For example, here is the quantity of food supplied for lunch on the 4th day of the trip: 625 lbs. of turkey, (yes, vegetarians had non-meat meals) 266 loaves of bread, 300 lbs. of cheese, 1,632 cans of soft drinks, 34 cases of Gatoraide, 2,000 lbs. of salad, 147 lbs. of bean sprouts, 44 flats of grapes, etc., etc. Camp sites are provided every evening. If you have never seen 1,500 tents set up on a high school football field, believe me it is a sight to see! Every evening portable showers are also set up and they never run out of hot water. Of course there is also a myriad of porta-potties. The ride also has four ambulances riding on the course, four Oregon State Motorcycle Troopers tooling along on the road plus five sag wagons. In addition, three different traveling bicycle repair shops set up free repair facilities every day, and 20-30 masseuses provided massages for a fee. For those who were thirsty, Full Sail Brewery, out of Hood River, set up a beer garden every evening. The ride is great to participate in just to see how this moving wheeled community flawlessly works. THE DAILY JOURNAL DAY ONE: Well, the first day we cycled from Athena (Elevation 1,734 ), located just north of Pendleton, to Elgin (Elevation 2,692). The ride was only about 45 miles in length; we had to climb one big hill (Peak Elevation 5,160). Lunch was at Spout Springs Ski Area (Elevation 5,028). Elgin is a community with the Wallowa Mountains to the east and the Blue Mountains to the west. Elgin's site was once the location of the Central Indian Camp of the Nez Perce tribe, and a trading area since the 1880s. Total climb: 4,150ft. DAY TWO: On day two we entered the beautiful Wallowa Valley, and had lunch in Wallowa. We cycled 54 miles and climbed 3,280ft. Camp was at Joseph (Elevation 4,247), a thriving art community located on the edge of the Eagle Cap Wilderness. DAY THREE: This was a tough day. The distance was 78 miles, and the total climb was 5,290ft. We had lunch overlooking Hells Canyon National Recreation Area. Hells Canyon is the deepest river gorge in North America, and a beautiful sight to see. After a sweet 17 mile decent into the Pine Valley, we camped at Halfway (Elevation 2,684), the home of Inga Thompson, former Olympic cycling medalist. DAY FOUR: We cycled 84 miles and climbed 4,800ft. Lunch was just outside Baker City at the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center. This is a special place to visit. They have wonderful life size displays of the pioneers traversing the Oregon Trail in the 1850s. You can still see the wagon wheel ruts in the high desert. Ah yes, the high desert. We cycled about 50 miles of desert today. It was hot, it was sunny and it was hard. About 50 riders sagged into the evening camp at Sumpter (Elevation 4,463). Sumpter, population 150, was a booming gold mining community and as recently as 1957 their gold dredge was still operating. The dredge can still be viewed on the edge of town. DAY FIVE: This day was only 46 miles, and the climbing was 3,280ft. We had lunch in Unity (Elevation 5,124), where we were treated to some wonderful foot-stomping, hand-clapping, fiddling music. We descended into Prairie City (Elevation 3,553), and saw to the west the beautiful backdrop of the Strawberry Mountains. DAY SIX: On this day we had a 72-mile ride and climbed 3,800 ft. During the many mining booms that hit Eastern Oregon, thousands of Chinese laborers were employed. John Day the first community we traveled through, is the site of the Kam Wah Museum, which celebrates the herbal medicine practice of the Chinese mine workers. Lunch was served at Fox (Elevation 4,387). After a few more hot and steep climbs, we dropped 10 fast miles into Monument (Elevation 2,013). Monument is an agricultural town bustling with activity in September. Hay, mint, apples and pears all come to harvest during September. DAY SEVEN: Whew, the last day. On one hand you�re pleased that the ride is finishing, but there is sadness knowing that the special magical event is almost over. We cycled 60 miles today and climbed 2,690ft. We had 40 miles of gentle downhill, and then a 2,100ft climb in ten miles. Then we dropped down to Fossil (Elevation 2,656), and finished the ride! ODDS & ENDS Yes, there were a few accidents on the ride, such as dislocated shoulders, fractured collar bones and road rash. However, the problems were small considering the number of cyclists on the road. A question frequently asked is �do you feel overwhelmed by all the people on the ride.� The answer is yes and no. While you are cycling along you are usually never out of sight of another cyclist, however you never feel hemmed in by other riders. The cyclists start riding at about 6 a.m. ( yes, it is still dark ), and continue getting on the road up to about 10 a.m. Thus, there is a line of cyclists stretching 40 miles down the road! Camping is an interesting experience. The number of riders and a finite amount of camping space require the tents to be set up close to one another. So, if by chance, you happen to set up your tent next to a person whom snores, well, I surely hope you have ear plugs! Usually there are lines to use the showers and porta-potties. All lines move quickly, and you can always strike up an interesting conversation with the bikies next to you. Although I don�t have statistics, My eyes lead me to believe that the average age of the cyclists was between 40-50 years. Most cyclists rode road bikes, but there were many mountain bikes, tandems, recumbents and folding bikes. The cyclists rode unencumbered. The ride provided six tractor trailer trucks to cart the cyclist�s gear from one campsite to another. There it is, It was another great Cycle Oregon ride and maybe I�ll see you there next year! If you�re interested in finding out more about Cycle Oregon, call 1 800-CYCLEOR or e-mail and they will put you on the mailing list for Cycle Oregon IX. Neil Mishalov 1995 Online Tourbook If you're participating in this years Cycle Oregon, you'll recognize that this is an online version of the Cycle Oregon Tourbook, which has been provided to you by the Oregonian (hope you're training for those hills!). If you're not a participant this year, we invite you to take a virtual ride over this years route. You will find a summary of each days ride, including elevation maps, mileage, elevation, menus, events, and local history and information. Click on map or below for detailed information on each days ride Day 1: Athena to Elgin Day 2: Elgin to Joseph Day 3: Joseph to Halfway Day 4: Halfway to Sumpter Day 5: Sumpter to Prairie City Day 6: Prairie City to Monument Day 7: Monument to Fossil Elevation Statistics Summary Send us your ideas on what you would like to see included here on Cycle Oregon Online -- enter "CycleOr" as subject We've gotten some GREAT input on what you would like to see online. Here are some of the ideas, many of which we are currently working on: Pictures of each days highlights A report of each days ride (perhaps Jonathan Nicholas' column from The Oregonian) Elevation maps of each days ride Message Board A list of participants, broken down by city, state and country A profile of each of the towns that are acting as hosts restaurants points of interest population "local talk" -- interviews with local citizens A special thanks to Charles Wright, Pete Magnuson, Mark Vanderford, Jeff Wright, Dean Heath and Richard Maliszewski for their input. Keep those great ideas coming! Each year, through sponsor and public support, we have collectively achieved our goal to enhance the quality of life for the children in our community. Albertina Kerr Centers for Children Chris Krenk, Chief Executive Officer Marcia Director, Director of Development & Volunteer Services The Albertina Kerr Centers has developed a technically sophisticated intervention process for the purpose of serving the community by enhancing the self-esteem, improving the physical and mental health, and promoting the self-responsibility of children and youth at risk, families in need, and individuals with disabilities. Boys & Girls Clubs of Portland Metropolitan Area Dick Hanlin, Executive Director Dana Gritzmacher, Development Director Boys & Girls Clubs of Portland is a nonprofit youth development agency with a mission to improve the quality of life for young people in our community. The organization operates facilities in Lents, Sellwood, Hillsboro, North Portland and Beaverton, as well as extension units in the Columbia Villa Housing project. Doernbecher Children's Hospital J.S. May, Executive Director Kathleen Shelton, Director Doernbecher Children's Hospital provides a vital range of services for thousands of children including the treatment of cancer, heart and kidney disease, cystic fibrosis and other inherited disorders, organ transplants, trauma, as well as primary care. The hospital takes care of virtually all children, regardless of the family's ability to pay. Hearing and Speech Institute Kristin Sorman, Director This non-profit community agency receives some 25,000 visits a year from people of all ages with communication disorders. Highly qualified speech-language pathologists and teachers use internationally recognized methods and materials pioneered by the Infant Hearing Resource program and guides children, teaching them games, songs and communication to prepare them for success in a hearing world in the Intensive Language program. Legacy Emanuel Children's Hospital Claudine Larocque, Annual Gifts Officer Michael Westby, Major Gifts Officer With an 80-year tradition of caring and medical excellence, Legacy Emanuel is the most comprehensive private pediatric hospital in Oregon. It has special teams of heatlhcare professionals to care for injuries related to children's burns, trauma, rehabilitation and development in a well-equipped neonatal special care unit; dedicated pediatric intensive care facility; Level I trauma center and Pediatric Critical Care Transport Program. March of Dimes Kathy Ellis, Executive Director Dennis Gilsdorf, Communications Director March of Dimes mission is the improve the health of babies by preventing birth defects and infant mortality through research, community service, education and advocacy. Through programs such as the Children's Center and Elizabeth House, which supplies case management services for pregnant teenagers, the March of Dimes Campaign for Healthier Babies helps to ensure a healthy and happy future for tomorrow's babies. Metropolitan Family Service Gary Withers, Executive Director Metropolitan Family Service is a private, nonprofit, nonsectarian, charitable family service agency that began operations in 1950 as a family counseling agency. Serving the tri-county metropolitan area, the agency has developed a growing family of services in response to changing community needs. The organization is committed to improving our community by preserving and strengthening all families and individuals. Providence Child Center Shoshana Grammer, Foundation Executive Director Charlene Dahlen, Director of Annual Giving Formerly known as Our Lady of Providence Nursery for adoptive babies when its doors first opened in 1945, the corridors of Providence Child Center are no longer a home for adoptive babies, but provide medical and educational services for disabled and non-disabled children in three very distinct programs: The Providence Montessori School with an emphasis on individual development and personal attention through professional Montessori instruction; the Emily School for preschool children with delayed development in social, communication or motor skills; and the Children's Nursing Center for severely disabled infants and children. A special thanks to The #1 Sports Site on the Web The Fred Meyer Challenge, held August 19-22 and hosted by PGA Tour star Peter Jacobsen, is the most popular non-PGA Tour golf event in the country. This years event is being televised by ESPN and is expected to draw a live audience of over 50,000. Pro's Comments Answers to your questions. Not your usual golf tournament James Achenbach, editor of GolfWeek thinks "The Fred Meyer Challenge is the most entertaining golf tournament you will ever see". Not Everyone knows Peter Jacobsen! Peter Jacobsen is one of the most popular pros on the PGA Tour. But not everyone in his home town knows him. Join Peter on a tour of The Oregon Golf Club Peter, the designer of The Oregon Golf Club, takes us on a tour of the course, describes each hole and how he plays it. About PJP Peter Jacobsen Productions, Inc. (PJP) is a sports event management and promotions company headquartered in Portland, Oregon and founded in 1988 by popular PGA Tour player and Northwest native Peter Jacobsen. PJP is respected nationally for its strong expertise in all aspects of event management and promotions. It specializes in event development, all phases of operations, advertising and promotions, and sales and marketing of corporate sponsorships. The company was originally created to manage and promote the successful and popular Fred Meyer Challenge, which has since become the number one non-PGA Tour event in golf and one of the most prestigious tournaments on the West Coast. Businesses recognize sports marketing as a viable method of increasing awareness and interaction with a very large audience. Media dollars must be targeted and spent wisely. PJP expertly customizes the needs of sponsors to fit specific budget levels. Each sponsorship is designed to give maximum exposure to effectively promote a company's products or services. To meet the distinct requirements and needs of each event, PJP provides the highest level of service in the following areas: Accounting & Financial Services Broadcast Advertising Consulting Services Concept & Development Corporate Marketing Materials Entertainment & Acquisitions Facilities Management Media Placement Media Relations Merchandising Print Advertising On-Site & Off-Site Event Promotions Pre-event & On-Site Operations Public Relations Sales & Marketing Sales Promotions Sponsorship Development Television Syndication Video Production Event Highlights Golf The Fred Meyer Challenge The Fred Meyer Challenge is the most unique golf tournament of its kind in the country. Nearly 50,000 people arrive at the prestigious Oregon Golf Club in West Linn, Oregon to watch 24 of the world's greatest golfers compete over two days for a $750,000 purse in the two-man, best-ball format. Peter Jacobsen serves as host for the annual three-day event, which is televised nationally and internationally. The event's one-day Pro-Am preceding regular play brings together PGA Tour stars, top celebrities and amateurs. It is recognized as one of the most exceptional pro-ams in the country. Each year hundreds of corporate sponsors participate in The Fred Meyer Challenge because it consistently provides their business with high levels of corporate and product exposure, as well as excellent entertainment. Nike Tour Championship The NIKE Tour gives aspiring young golfers and former PGA Tour members an opportunity to hone their skills in competitions across the country. Through 72 holes and four days of grueling competition, the top 50 money winners on the NIKE Tour battle for the rights to be called champion and gain entry into the PGA Tour. For two years the NIKE Tour Championship event was held at the highly-touted Pumpkin Ridge Golf Club in Cornelius, Oregon. PJP managed and promoted the NIKE Tour Championship, which took place on the club's challenging Ghost Creek course. The Skins Game PJP was originally retained by Westinghouse Desert Communities, Inc. to secure the rights for The Skins Game at Bighorn Golf Club, Palm Desert, California. Since that successful negotiation, Desert Communities has retained PJP as the exclusive management team for the event. Cycling Cycle Oregon Capturing the flavor of the Northwest by bicycle, cyclists arrive from all parts of the world to experience Oregon's scenic beauty, small-town warmth and long-lasting friendships in the Cycle Oregon bicycle tour. Every September, the much anticipated week-long Cycle Oregon trek takes 2,000 cyclists through nearly 500 miles of beautiful, rural Oregon. PJP has enhanced the success and enjoyment of this events with its sales and marketing expertise and by streamlining the enormous logistical operations, earning praise from participants. Basketball Ford Far West Classic Intense competition characterizes the annual showcase of college basketball talent at the Ford Far West Classic. A holiday tradition since the 1950s, the University of Oregon and Oregon State University men's basketball teams meet in Portland in December for two nights of doubleheader contests with top NCAA teams from across the nation. The Ford Far West Classic is one of the oldest and most respected holiday basketball tournaments in America. In 1994, PJP joined forces with the NBA Portland Trail Blazers as "Classic Productions" to enhance the popularity of the December tournament, which subsequently enjoyed an increase in attendance of 62%. Hockey Icenost Billed as "IceNost," PJP organized and promoted and organized this event bringing 8,000 fans to the Memorial Coliseum in Portland, Oregon to watch the best of the United States and USSR hockey teams. Team USA played an exhibition game against the Soviet Union National Team in a final tune-up for the Goodwill Games held in Seattle, Washington the following month. The Soviets came from behind in the third period to win 5-3. The U.S. team went on to win the Silver Medal in the 1990 Goodwill Games, losing in a dramatic sudden-death shoot out with the Soviets for the Gold Metal. In addition to Olympic hockey, PJP has promoted five National Hockey League exhibition games. Boat Racing River City Grand Prix More than 25,000 spectators attended Portland's first International Outboard Grand Prix (IOGP) racing event held on the Willamette River. PJP organized the successful two-day summer race, which was the third stop in the eight race IOGP series. The circuit, sanctioned by the American Power Boat Association, featured three classes of boats (Champ, MOD-VP and SST-140) raced by 50 to 60 teams from the United States, Canada and Europe. Corporate sponsor chalets, which lined the northern end of Tom McCall Waterfront Park promenade along the Willamette River, were graced with spectacular viewing of the fast paced, highly competitive race, where boats with up to 300 horsepower engines reached top speeds of 140 mph. Peter Jacobsen Productions, Inc. This is the Great Basin Country, a star-spangled landscape of marsh and mountain, of reflection and rimrock, of seamless vistas and sage-scented dreams. Come join us on Cycle Oregon IX. We promise a ride you'll never forget. Jonathan Nicholas President, Cycle Oregon, Inc. Cycle Oregon IX Cycle Oregon is a seven-day, non-competitive bicycle tour that explores a different region of rural Oregon each year. Two thousand cyclists visit several overnight communities with a full complement of services and amenities along the way. Registration The registration fee is $435 per person ($870 for tandem rriders) and the field is limited to the first 2,000 riders whose registration forms are received in the Cycle Oregon office with a postmark of April 1 or later. To request a registration brochure and application, or to express your interest in volunteering for Cycle Oregon, call 503-643-8064 or 800-292-5367.
