Curt Simkins -- McMinnville, OR USA Cycle for Life My name is Curt Simkins and I will be working with the Oregon Chapter of the American Cancer Society in a fund raising effort to help fight cancer. This past April I lost my step-father to liver cancer and have had several other family members and friends that have had to face this terrible disease. In their spirit of accepting a challenge, I have decided to take part in Cycle Oregon this September, but with an added degree of difficulty. I will doubling back frequently, and plan to cover 125-150 miles per day in the mountains of northeastern Oregon for a total of 1000 miles for the week. My intended goal is to raise $10,000 and I would appreciate your support very much. Contributions are 100% tax deductable. You can either sign up on a pledge sheet for a certain amount per mile (1-5 cents/mile) or you can donate a set amount. Checks should be made out to the American Cancer Society and I will see that you get a receipt. You can also sign up with me during the ride. Our first stop is Spout Springs, a skiing wonderland in winter and mountain bike haven in summer. On the way UP to this scenic spot, take a moment a look around (it's much too easy to keep your focus down when you're traveling skyward) and especially back towards Athena. The transition from rolling wheat country to the Blue Mountains is truly spectacular. At the top, the reward is two-fold: a delicious lunch followed by a wonderful downhill cruise to Elgin. Elgin, named after the song, "Lost on the Lady Elgin" is a thriving community of 1,775 surrounded by nature at its finest. With the Wallowa Mountains to the east and the Blue Mountains to the west, the town site was once the location of the Central Indian Camp for the Nez Perce tribe, the former location of Fort Baker and a trading area since the 1880s. It's fortunate the days mileage is short, for the community is long on entertainment. You'll be treated to everything from a cowboy ballet and western dancing to a tuba band and three-act play. Today we enter the magical Wallowa Valley. The beauty and wonder of this area is truly astounding; it doesn't take long to understand why those who visit are compelled to return. In Wallowa, lunch is served at the site of the annual Wallowa Band Nez Perce Pow Wow and Friendship Feast. Wallowa County provided the last stronghold of the Wallowa Band of Nez Perce Indians. Chief Joseph, noted for his commitment to his people and the land, left behind a legacy that endures to this day. Today, residents depend on the land for their livelihoods in farming, ranching, logging and milling. It's a small (pop. 800) close knit community where everyone greets everyone with a smile. On our way to Joseph, our overnight destination, we pass through the largest of the Wallowa Valley communities, Enterprise (population 1,940). All kinds of surprises can happen in Enterprise, so be ready! On the way out of town, watch the fields to the right for the big black Clysdale work horses bred and raised here. Nestled on the edge of the Eagle Cap Wilderness, we finally come to Joseph, a thriving art community bustling with charm. With much to see and do here, it may be difficult to take advantage of all the town has to offer. Whether it's a visit to one of the many galleries, shops or museums, you won't be disappointed. (Joseph merchants have kindly agreed to extend their hours just for us!) In terms of entertainment, if there's a theme to be had, think Cowboys! Just outside of town is beautiful Wallowa Lake. Consider taking the tram up to the summit of Mt. Howard (elevation 8,300 ft.) for some spectacular views. For those of you mountain bikers, consider exploring some true wilderness. Call Paul Grow, (503) 432-2453, for further information. ELGIN BREAKFAST, 6:00-8:30 A.M. Smoked Salmon Hash; Vegetarian Hash; Granola; Cinnamon Roll; Whole Fruit; Bagels; Cream Cheese; Peanut Butter; Jam; Yogurt WALLOWA LUNCH, 10:00 A.M. - 1:00 P.M. Thai Noodle Chicken Salad; Vegetarian Thai Salad with Sunflower Seeds; Whole Grain Rolls; Sesame Cabbage Salad with Pineapple; Asian Pears; Macadamia Nut Cookie; Fortune Cookie JOSEPH DINNER, 4:30 - 7:30 P.M. As Hells Canyon National Recreation Area celebrates it 20th anniversary this year, it seems fitting that Cycle Oregon help in the occasion. Sitting on the edge of the deepest river gorge in North America, eating a delicious lunch prepared by the Eastern Oregon Visitors Association, you'll be looking at thousands of years of Mother Nature's work. In the spring, the area is covered with wildflowers; in the fall, sumac and quaking aspen sets the area ablaze with vivid reds, bright golds and yellows. The Canyon itself is teeming with wildlife. Rocky Mountain elk, mule and white-tail deer, black bear, bighorn sheep, eagles and hawks are but a few of the residents. Our descent to Halfway will take us into Pine Valley where our perspective of the Eagle Cap Wilderness is just as dramatic as it was in Joseph. In Halfway, literally our halfway point on the ride, residents do things in big way. There's the big pit BBQ being prepared on our behalf; there's the exclusive Cycle Oregon raffle -- a four day, three night, all-inclusive white water raft trip for two on the Snake River being raffled to Cycle Oregon participants only; there's Inga Thompson, a Halfway resident and former Olympic cycling medalist, who will be giving a cycling clinic (if interested, please call the Cycle Oregon office by August 25); and there is much more. Pocket Sandwich with Chicken Spread; Humus Sandwich; Angel Hair Pasta with Greek Olives; Greek Pasta Salad; Fruit Salad; Whole Wheat Crackers; Apple; Oregon Trail Mix; Baklava HALFWAY DINNER, 4:30 - 7:30 P.M. You've got a rather long day in the saddle today. There are more hills to climb. It could get hot. Massage appointments will fill up fast. But remember, at least you've got rest stops, sag wagons, delicious meals, hot showers and a beer garden on hand at various points on the course. If you had been one of the early pioneers who came out on the Oregon Trail, it would have been a whole different story. So when you visit the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center, location of our lunch this day, remember to keep things in perspective. Inside the Center, living history demonstrations, life sized dioramas, numerous displays and exhibits pay tribute to the courage of the emigrants and the hardship of the Oregon Trail. (Note: when entering the Center, please check cleats and water bottles at the door.) Our lunch is being hosted by the Baker County Visitor and Convention Bureau. Continuing on, we ride through historic Baker City, one of few Western cities whose ornate turn-of-the-century architecture is still intact. Tucked against the dramatic backdrop of the Elkhorn Mountains, this "Queen City of the Mines," as it used to be called, was a booming mining community near the turn of the century. Sumpter, our overnight destination, was also a booming mining community and as recently as 1957 their gold dredge was still operating. Today, the dredge can still be viewed at the State Park located at the edge of town and the original narrow gauge steam locomotive from Sumpter still operates. During our stay, mining and logging demonstrations will take place. Check out the antique shops or witness the "pony express" in action. HALFWAY BREAKFAST, 6:00 - 8:30 A.M. Cornmeal Mush; Boiled Eggs; Granola; Assorted Danishes; English Muffins; Whole Fruit; Peanut Butter; Jam; Yogurt INTERPRETIVE CENTER LUNCH, 10:00 A.M. - 1:00 P.M. Turkey Pastrami, Pickle on Rye with Honey Sauce and Swiss Cheese; Vegetarian Sandwich; Provolone, Smoked Almonds, Leaf Lettuce, Tomato on Whole Wheat; Santa Fe Pasta Salad; Lemon Linguine Salad; Grapes; Cheese Popcorn; Brownies SUMPTER DINNER , 4:30 - 7:30 P.M. First, after two short-but-sweet climbs over Dixie and Tipton mountains, we will be greeted by some foot-stomping, hand-clapping, fiddlin' music. It comes to us courtesy of the good folk of Unity, our lunch hosts, who have traveled several miles to meet us with a good meal and a warm welcome. Unity, located in Oregon's Burnt River Valley, is one of four ranching communities in the area. Descending into Prairie City, we are greeted by another dramatic backdrop, this time from the Strawberry Mountains and the vast wilderness area they encompass. It's a beautiful setting for the evening activities which include everything from a natural history slide show, gold panning exhibition and cowboy poetry. Prairie City was once the western terminus of the Sumpter Valley Railroad. Check out the depot museum, open for your enjoyment. SUMPTER BREAKFAST, 6:00 - 8:30 A.M. Scrambled Eggs; Cold Cereal; Whole Fruit; Bagels; Cream Cheese; Peanut Butter; Jam; Yogurt; Croissant; Raisins UNITY LUNCH, 10:00 A.M. - 1:00 P.M. Crab Pasta Salad with 12-grain Roll; Parisian Pasta Salad; Rye Crisp; Peaches; Pretzels; Caramel; Cheese Bread Sticks; Tapioca Pudding PRAIRIE CITY DINNER , 4:30 - 7:30 P.M. Lasagna; Vegetarian Lasagna; Caesar Salad; Marinated Veggie Salad; Garlic Breadsticks; Broccoli Slaw; Ricotta Cheesecake with Marionberry Sauce [Challenge][Skins Game][Far West Classic] [Cycle Oregon][Sponsors][Course Directory][PJP Info][Home Page] Created and Developed by: Multimedia Marketing Group Inc © Copyright 1995, 1996All Rights ReservedWT03-B27-40IA058-000946-B004-284http://www.pjp.com:80/day6.html 198.5.254.122 19970208043657 text/html 4218HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:36:10 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 05:39:21 GMTContent-length: 4042 Cycle OREGON - Bicycle Tour Day 6: Prairie City to Monument 72 miles Elevation Start: 3,553 High Point: 5,075 Elevation Finish: 2,013 		  Segment	 Cumulative	Elevation    Feet/Mile	John Day	12.24 miles	12.24 miles	  3,144	    33 downhillRest Stop	 8.35 miles	20.59 miles	  2,874	    32 downhillMt. Vernon	  .85 miles	21.44 miles	  2,877	     4 uphillPeak		16.45 miles 	37.89 miles	  4,687	   110 uphillFox (Lunch)	 5.41 miles	43.30 miles	  4,387	    55 downhillPeak		 2.67 miles	45.97 miles	  5,075	   258 uphillLong Creek	 4.31 miles	50.28 miles	  3,787	   299 downhillPeak		 3.69 miles	53.97 miles	  4,206	   114 uphillRest Stop 	 3.45 miles	57.42 miles	  4,211	     1 uphillPeak		 2.05 miles 	59.47 miles	  4,337	    61 uphill	Hamilton	 2.27 miles	61.74 miles	  3,662	   297 downhillMonument	10.07 miles	71.81 miles	  2,013	   164 downhill During the numerous mining booms that hit Eastern Oregon, thousands of Chinese laborers were employed. John Day, the first community we travel through on this day, is the site of the Kam Wah Museum which celebrates the herbal medicine practices of these mine workers. After John Day, we head for the community of Fox, a small farming hamlet where lunch will be served by the spirited folks from Long Creek, the next community on the route. Unfortunately, the mileage was too long for us to actually serve lunch in Long Creek. But that didn't stop them, for they came to us. While you're eating, be sure to look at the drawings on display produced by the elementary school children in the area. You'll have a chance to vote for your favorite few and watch awards being presented. Down the road, when passing through Long Creek, take note of their 1991 centennial sign on display. Long Creek has the dubious distinction of having experienced the worse tornado ever to hit Oregon. On June 3, 1891, 200 mph winds blasted the community, destroying most of the original homesteads. Let's just hope if we experience similar winds they'll be blowing at our backs! Monument, our overnight host community, is an agricultural town bustling with activity in September. Hay, mint, apples and pears all come to harvest. As bountiful as the crops are, they're no match for the generous welcome planned for our arrival. Whether you partake of the street dance or indulge in some of the homemade treats (and crafts) on hand, you're sure to end the day with a smile. PRAIRIE CITY BREAKFAST, 6:00 - 8:30 A.M. Sausages; Buttermilk Biscuits & Gravy; Granola; Muffins; Whole Fruit; Yogurt; Butter & Honey; Breakfast Bar; Raisin Bread LONG CREEK LUNCH, 10:00 A.M. - 1:00 P.M. Roast Beef Sandwich; Veggie Sandwich, Cucumber, Cheese, Sprouts, Tomato, Onion; Macaroni Salad; Olive and Herb Salad; Carrot Sticks; Tortilla Chips; Lemon Parfait MONUMENT DINNER , 4:30 - 7:30 P.M. Shrimp Creole; Black Beans; White Rice; Veggie Creole; Cajun Pasta Salad; Sweet Potatoes; Spinach Salad; Pears; Pecan Pie with Whipped Cream [Challenge][Skins Game][Far West Classic] [Cycle Oregon][Sponsors][Course Directory][PJP Info][Home Page] Created and Developed by: Multimedia Marketing Group Inc © Copyright 1995, 1996All Rights ReservedWT03-B27-41IA058-000946-B004-346http://www.pjp.com:80/day7.html 198.5.254.122 19970208043718 text/html 3806HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:37:29 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 05:39:23 GMTContent-length: 3630 Cycle OREGON - Bicycle Tour Day 7: Monument to Fossil 60 miles Elevation Start: 2,013 High Point: 3,788 Elevation Finish: 2,656 		  Segment	 Cumulative	Elevation   Feet/MileCampground	11.14 miles	11.14 miles	  1,894	     10 downhillCampground	 1.21 miles	12.35 miles	  1,871	     19 downhillKimberly	 1.75 miles	14.10 miles	  1,832	     22 downhillSpray (lunch)	12.23 miles 	26.33 miles	  1,830	           -Campground	11.21 miles	37.54 miles	  1,702	     11 downhillStore		 2.18 miles	39.72 miles	  1,689	      6 downhillWater Stop	 1.98 miles	41.70 miles	  2,030	    172 uphillHenderson Pk	 6.00 miles	47.70 miles	  3,133	    184 uphillShelton		  .76 miles	48.46 miles	  3,356	    293 uphillLAST PEAK	 1.27 miles 	49.73 miles	  3,788	    340 uphillCampground	 2.66 miles	52.39 miles	  3,301	    183 downhillForestry HQ	 1.22 miles	53.61 miles	  3,142	    130 downhillFossil		 5.53 miles	59.14 miles	  2,656	     88 downhill This is it, your last day in the saddle. What a week it's been! After today, NO MORE HILLS! After today, a lot of good memories. Make the most of the smiles and warm welcomes guaranteed to greet you, introduce yourself to that cyclist you've been wanting to meet all week. Spray, our lunch host, is a small community, population 150. As you pedal into town, make a stop at the church built at the turn-of-the-century that has been restored and is now a museum. While you're eating, enjoy the spirited western sounds of the Wheeler County Trio. In Fossil, be prepared for a hero's welcome, as the town's school children greet you with genuine joy. This community, named after the discovery of some fossilized bones of an elephant, has never been known to do anything in a small way. You'll receive a special fossil-like gift, be part of a wonderful surprise and realize, if you haven't already, that you have much to proud of in completing Cycle Oregon VIII. CLOSING CEREMONIES, 7:30 P.M.Fossil Fair and Rodeo Grounds. Bicycles loaded or shipped via UPS 2:00 - 7:00 P.M. MONUMENT BREAKFAST, 6:00 - 8:30 A.M. And at the heart of the Princeville experience is golf. Robert Trent Jones, Jr. has fashioned 45 of the most beautiful holes of golf in the world. They range along green bluffs that skirt mountains and the bluest ocean, offering stunning views everywhere you look. Golf Digest has honored the Prince Course with its highest accolade: number one among all golf courses in the State of Hawaii. Also ranked number 43 in "America's 100 Greatest Golf Courses." And Golf Magazine has named Princeville a "Gold Medal Resort." Golf Digest also rated the Makai Course number seven in Hawaii. We launch PJP Online with coverage of The Fred Meyer Challenge, the most popular non-PGA golf event in the world. Information on Corporate Sponsorships Information on Golf Course Directory Sponsorships Benefits of PJP Online Sponsorship include: High Viewership & Visibility We continue our relationship with ESPN this year, as they once again televise The Challenge. Our online presence benefits from this relationship, as ESPN's WWW site, called ESPNet Sports Zone, is the third most popular Web site, averaging 8,500,000 visits per week by 2,000,000 viewers. ESPN will provide a hyperlink from their popular site to The Challenge Online, assuring that your message will be seen by hundreds of thousands of viewers from around the world. Choice Demographics Consider these Internet demographics from the 3rd WWW User Survey, conducted in April-May of this year by the Graphic, Visualization & Usability Center at the Georgia Institute of Technology: average age of Internet users -- 35 80.3% male, 20% female average income -- $70,000 50% are online between 2-6 hours/week; 45.3% are online more; 4.8% are online less typically college educated typically interested in technology, electronics, movies, automobiles, books Support Children's Charities The Fred Meyer Challenge is proud to have contributed over $3,700,000 to Portland Area Children's Charities over the last nine years. Your online sponsorship will help us continue this proud tradition. Option on Online Sponsorship Next Year As the Internet and the World Wide Web continue their explosive growth, it's becoming increasingly important to have an online presence. Your participation this year reserves your spot for next year at guaranteed rates. 4398HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:23:26 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 05:06:20 GMTContent-length: 4222 Oregon Golf Club Facts The Oregon Golf Club Golf Course Fact Sheet Follow Peter Jacobsen as he describes each hole Course Characteristics Yardage Jacobsen -- 7,034 Championship -- 6,558 Member -- 6,046 Forward -- 5,345 Course Terrain: Rolling Hills Soil Condition Fairways & Rough: Clay Loam Greens & Tees: Constructed to USGA specifications Grass Varities Greens: Pennlinks Creeping Bentgrass Tees: Pennlinks Creeping Bentgrass Fairways: Bardot Colonial Bentgrass Rough: Champion Perennial Ryegrass Average Green: 6,200 square feet Average Tee: 1,360 square feet Fairway Acreage: 34 Rough Acreage: 150 Sand Bunkers: 76 Water Hazards 2 streams 2 ponds 1 lake Green Speed: Stimpmeter readings average 9.5 Rounds per Year: 20,000 Course Maintenance Aerification Schedule Greens & Tees: Late Spring & early Fall Fairways: Late Spring & early Fall (Verti-Drain November-March) Top Dressing Program: Greens & Tees every 2-3 weeks, March-November Drainage Conditions: Excellent Irrigation System: Toro Network 8000 Source of Water: Willamette River Mowing Height Greens: 1/8" Tees: 1/4" Fairways: 7/16" Rough: 1 1/2" Environmental Practices Management of wildlife food and cover Integrated pest management program (limited use of pesticides and fertilizers) Monitoring of water resources for water quality and wildlife potential Water conservation measures Encourage member and public involvement to help achieve environmental goals Wildlife on Golf Course Blue Heron, Ringneck Pheasant, Osprey Eagle, Bald Eagle, Golden Eagle, Great Horned Owl, Turkey Vulture, Pileated Woodpecker, Redtail Hawk, Coyote, Raccoon, White and Black-Tail Deer, Mountain Beaver, Elk, Mountain Lion Superintendent Information Course Superintendent: John Anderson Years at The Oregon Golf Club: 4 Course History/Interesting Facts Founded July 4, 1992 The golf course offers some of the Portland area's most dramatic views of Mt. Hood, Mt. Adams and Mt. St. Helens Twentieth golf course in the United States to become fully certified in the Audubon Cooperative Sanctuary Program for Golf Courses, sponsored by the USGA and the Audubon Society of New York State. Annual site of The Fred Meyer Challenge, hosted by Peter Jacobsen MOre than 3,000 roses are planted on the course Recieved national recognition for winning the grand prize -- commercial division in the American Association of Rose Society's "Landscape with Roses" contest. Other Key Course Personnel Course Architects: Peter Jacobsen & Ken Kavanaugh General Manager: Rick Mant Director of Golf: Peter Jacobsen Head Golf Professional: Craig Griswold Assistant Superintendent: Bruce Brower, GCSAA [Tickets][Players][Sponsors][Scoring][Media Guide][Charities] [Course Directory][Challenge Home][Home] Created and Developed by: Multimedia Marketing Group Inc © Copyright 1995, 1996 All Rights ReservedWT03-B27-48IA089-000953-B048-352http://www.pjp.com:80/golfweek.html 198.5.254.122 19970208041258 text/html 6278HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:12:28 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 05:09:22 GMTContent-length: 6102 Fred Meyer Challenge Scoring A Unique Perspective For An Unusual Golf Tournament by James Achenbach, Senior Editor, GOLFWEEK You think being a golf journalist is a piece of cake? Hey, sometimes I'd rather be run over by a greens mower. Working alongside professional golfers -- and writing about them regularly -- is no easy task. Friendships with players, for example, can be an impediment to objective journalism. There has to be a clear distinction between reporting the news (telling the truth, if you will) and being a friend. There has to be a line in the sand, over which an ethical writer will not step. It may sound unorthodox or even revolting, but I am not in the business of creating friendships. I have known Paul Azinger for more than 20 years. I knew him when he played on his high school golf team and would shoot 35 one day and 45 the next. Nine holes with him was an adventure to be continued, and there is no way I can adequately express the depth of my admiration for what he has accomplished. Because of our professions, however, we became adversaries as much as friends. Once I had a prolonged difference of opinion (I am tempted to call it a war of words) with Curtis Strange, who didn't agree with something I wrote. It was a very unpleasant experience. Even Peter Jacobsen, who gets along with everybody in cleats, has not exactly been my greatest admirer. "You're too critical," he pronounced one day. So why did Peter's event management company, which produces The Fred Meyer Challenge, ask me to write this article? I guess Peter Jacobsen Productions thought I would tell the truth, which in this case is simple: The Fred Meyer Challenge is the most entertaining golf tournament you will ever see -- anywhere, any time. Entertaining in the sense that it combines effervescent personalities and great golf shots better than any other tournament I know. Entertaining in the sense that a lot of money, $750,000, is on the line, and yet the players joke around as if it were a $2 Nassau. Be assured, however, that the competition is very serious. You can see it clearly in the emotion-filled faces of the players as they contend with The Oregon Golf Club's outrageously tough 18th, which may be the most difficult closing hole in America. My idea of a nightmare? I have to break 90, or the devil takes my soul. I get to the course and realize that all 18 holes are the same -- the uphill, creek-lined, bunker-protected 18th at The Oregon Golf Club. Peter must have finished his tax return the night before he designed this diabolical hole. Speaking of Peter, the free-wheeling personality of The Fred Meyer Challenge is a tribute to his distinctive character and to his popularity among players on the PGA Tour. Could anyone else assemble such a fabulous lineup of players and celebrities? Yes, but I can think of only three or four superstars who could pull it off. And the founder of the Flounders (that's the mock musical group Jake Trout and the Flounders) is right at the top of the list. How strong is the field for this year's event? Together these players have won almost three dozen major professional championships. This is golf at its best -- past, present and future, from the legendary Arnold Palmer, 65, to the soon-to-be legendary Ernie Els, 25. And how many golf fans have had the opportunity to see Jack and son Gary Nicklaus play together in a team event? Not many. In my mind, this alone is worth the price of admission. What happens when you put players of this magnitude in the friendly, no-pressure atmosphere of The Fred Meyer Challenge? It's like dynamite, all this golfing talent exploding in a let-'er-rip environment. Boom! The byproduct is an astounding collection of daring golf shots. If you're like me, you'll be amazed by what you see. The skill of these golfers is phenomenal. I love the sounds as well as the sights. I love standing by a tee, listening to the whack of the ball and watching the flight pattern as it soars toward the tree tops. But the bottom line, as Peter would wish, is the camaraderie and the fellowship. This is golf, the best of all games, played by a fraternity of some the most gifted golfers to lace on cleats and spike the face of the earth. The Fred Meyer Challenge is unique. But it's more than that -- it's something to be thankful for. A tournament like this doesn't just happen overnight. All the stars in the heavens must have been lined up in the just the right fashion when this event fell into place. I know of no other golf tournament quite like it. It's enough to make me cross that line in the sand. It's enough to make me think about new friendships. Oh boy, this tournament must be getting to me. Excuse me while I go write a few nasty words about somebody. [Tickets][Players][Sponsors][Scoring][Media Guide][Charities] [Course Directory][Challenge Home][Home] Created and Developed by: Multimedia Marketing Group Inc © Copyright 1995, 1996 All Rights ReservedWT03-B27-49IA057-000945-B043-335http://www.pjp.com:80/fil.html 198.5.254.122 19970208041334 text/html 3134HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:13:39 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Thu, 19 Oct 1995 17:53:29 GMTContent-length: 2958 Fred Meyer Challenge Scoring Fil Pearl, Peter Jacobsen's Personal Trainer, Describes when he first realized Peter was a PGA Tour player "In 1990 when I was managing a club in Lake Oswego, I would see Jan, his wife, there all the time. I got to know Peter through the gym. His personality and mine...we're both very talkative. We started talking and he was very funny. At that time I had long hair. I was still playing bass in a rock band, so we had that common interest, although I did notice he talked an awful lot about golf. I didn't know his last name, and I had no idea what he did. I just knew he was a nice guy, was funny, and liked rock 'n roll. He showed me a tape of the Flounders, and I still didn't have any idea what he did for a living. "At the gym everybody talked to Peter about golf and I can remember thinking, 'Boy, he's obviously into this thing.' I've never played golf; never done it, ever. I said to Peter, 'Look, you are obviously into golf. Why don't we go out one day, go out to the muni here and hit some balls? I've never played and it would be fun.' He graciously agreed to do that. He said, 'I'll hit some balls with you, but I'm going to be gone for three weeks. When I get back in town...' "As fate would have it, that weekend I was watching TV, flipping through the channels and came upon the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic. They kept talking about Peter Jacobsen. I didn't really pay attention because I didn't really know his last name. Peter had a cap on. He had just won and at this point they zoomed in for a close up. I thought, 'Oh my God, that's the guy from the gym! He's a pro golfer and he just won!' And then, of course, it all fell into place. "When Peter came back home, he was ready to hit some balls. I said, 'No way, I'm not gonna do that.' To this day, if we're at The Oregon Golf Club, he'll try to give me instruction. I would prefer that my first experience with a golf ball not be in front of that guy." [Tickets][Players][Sponsors][Scoring][Media Guide][Charities] [Course Directory][Challenge Home][Home] Created and Developed by: Multimedia Marketing Group Inc © Copyright 1995, All Rights ReservedWT03-B27-50IA057-000945-B044-70http://www.pjp.com:80/18.html 198.5.254.122 19970208041420 text/html 8238HTTP/1.0 200 Document followsDate: Sat, 08 Feb 1997 04:14:05 GMTServer: NCSA/1.4.1Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 05:04:47 GMTContent-length: 8062 Fred Meyer Challenge Scoring Playing the Course Peter Jacobsen takes you on a tour of The Oregon Golf Club # 1 - Par 5 - 560 Yards We built a big, wide-open par 5 to let the player get off to a comfortable start. The second shot, ideally, will be hit over a large fairway bunker which we call the "hell bunker," after the trap at St. Andrews. The best approach to the green is from the left side of the fairway. I'll probably use a driver, 3-wood and 9-iron. # 2 - Par 4 - 369 Yards The player must be aggressive on this par 4 to carry it to the top of the hill, which then opens up a view to the green. If you lay up to avoid a fairway bunker on the left side, you will have a semi-blind downhill second shot. We put bunkers and long grass over near the tee boxes of Hole 3 to discourage players from trying a shortcut to the right. I'll use a driver and a wedge. # 3 - Par 4 - 437 Yards This par 4 reminds me of a hole in Scotland, with tall grass growing along the side. We have bordered the left side with many fairway bunkers to keep the player from short-cutting the hole down that side. There are no hazards in front of the green, so if there's a wind from the east, you can bounce your ball up. I'll hit a driver down the right side of the fairway, and then a 4- or 5-iron to the large green. # 4 - Par 3 - 162 Yards A downhill par 3 hole, dominated by Mt. Hood in the background. The player's tee shot goes right at the mountain. A massive oak tree guards the right side of the green, and a natural spring lake guards the left. I'll play anywhere from a 3- to 5-iron, depending on the pin position. This will be a very difficult hole to birdie. # 5 - Par 5 - 591 Yards A par 5 that's reachable in two shots. The drive needs to reach a plateau, and the second shot needs to carry a bunker in front of the green in order to reach it in two. If not, you've got to lay the ball up left, or play long to the right, to give you a short pitch to the green, which is guarded by another huge oak tree. I'll use a driver and a 3-wood to try to reach it in two. # 6 - Par 4 - 435 Yards A spectacular hole. The player must have a very good downhill drive, between two groves of trees, to set up his second shot. This par 4 is tough to reach in two, so there's a lot of area for chipping. I'll use a driver and a 3-iron, and I'll bring my short game with me. # 7 - Par 4 - 411 Yards A fun, interesting par 4. We tee off straight down the hill, and the second shot will be to a very narrow green. You can bounce the ball on the green from the left side, but if you miss it to the right, you'll be in the water. I'll probably play a 3-wood to the right center of the fairway, and a 6-iron to the green. # 8 - Par 3 - 204 Yards This hole is one of the toughest holes on the course. The green is protected on the right by a creek, and on the left by some tough bunkers. There is a flat, fair green; just a tough tee shot. This is a 4- or 5-iron shot for me. # 9 - Par 4 - 342 Yards I really enjoyed building this par 4 hole. We built the tees on the dike that was already there. The further back on the dike you hit, the more water you have to carry. We'll be hitting from the back and our drives will have to carry about 235 yards over the water and two fairway bunkers. The second shot is very short, to a green that looks a lot like the 3rd green at Augusta National. I'll hit a long, hard driver and an 8- or a 9-iron. # 10 - Par 4 - 361 Yards This is one of my favorite holes - the sharp dogleg right makes it a driveable par 4. The player can either lay up with a 2-iron down the left side, or use a wood and go for the green. It's a big, fair green and I purposely left a lot of open area around the green for chipping, because I want to entice the player to go for it. I definitely will be trying to hit a driver onto this green every time I play the hole. # 11 - Par 4 - 400 Yards This hole is cut right out of the trees, and looks like something out of Tokatee or Spyglass Hill. This is not a difficult par 4, but make sure you hit the green with your second shot -- it's well guarded by bunkers. I'll use a driver and probably a 7- or 8-iron. # 12 - Par 3 - 155 Yards This, along with number 18, amy be the signature hole of the course. A stunning par 3, with the tees and green cut into opposite sides of hills on either side of a canyon. I'll be hitting a 7- or 8-iron to a narrow green. # 13 - Par 4 - 443 Yards A tough par 4 hole. If you don't reach the green, you pay a penalty -- there's a creek that runs in front of the green. This creek will always be maintained with just a trickle of water so that you can play the ball out of the creek if you put it in there. I'll probably use a driver and a 2- or 3-iron. # 14 - Par 4 - 431 Yards This par 4 hole is power golf. It's an uphill tee shot to a very wide-open fairway. You must have a strong drive and an equally strong second shot to the largest green on the course, about 10,000 square feet. I'll hit a driver and then a 3-wood. I don't think you'll see very many birdies on this hole. # 15 - Par 5 - 517 Yards On this dogleg-right par 5, you've got to smack your drive far enough to be able to get around the corner to the right. If not, you'll have to lay up. The same creek that runs in front of 13 cuts in front of the 15th green. If I hit a good drive, I'll attack the flag with a 1- or 2-iron. If I hit a poor drive, I'll lay up with a 5- or 6-iron and go in with a wedge. # 16 - Par 4 - 440 Yards I want the player to be at the top of his game as he finishes his round. This tough, uphill par 4 requires a solid, straight drive down the right side to avoid fairway bunkers on the left. You must be in perfect position to have a good angle at this well-bunkered green. For me, this hole is a driver and a 4-iron. # 17 - Par 3 - 182 Yards A beautiful, tricky par 3. It almost has the illusion of a dogleg-left par 3 because the green wraps behind some of the tall trees that are down the hill to the left. When the pin is back and left, this will be a very difficult hole to play. I'll use a 3- or 4-iron. # 18 - Par 4 - 449 Yards A tough final hole. From the back tees on this par 4, we will have extremely difficult drives. There is only about 30 yards of safe landing area from back there. If the player is fortunate enough to hit a good drive, he'll have a tough long-iron shot uphill to a semi-blind green. This is a great spectator hole. The tournament will likely be won and lost on number 18. Refunds will be sent to those whose written cancellation is received by 5:00 P.M. Thursday, August 1, 1996. A $50 cancellation fee will be assessed. No faxed cancellations will be accepted. No refunds for any reason, medical or otherwise, will be allowed after August 1, 1996. One person per form Registration form must be signed - it is incomplete without a signature. If you wish to apply with other cyclists as a group, applications must be submitted in the same envelope. Each envelope may contain up to six individual applications. Registrations are not transferable. Riders under age 18 must be accompanied by an adult over 21. You will receive notification of your acceptance, non-acceptance or waiting list status within 4-6 weeks from our receiving your application. If accepted, you will receive a Rider handbook with full details by June 1. The route, which changes every year, is one of Oregon's most closely guarded secrets. Watch for this years route to be announced here on March 12th. And while you wait, get psyched by taking a virtual tour of Cycle Oregon VIII. Held September 10 - 16, 1995, cyclists traveled 450 miles through the breathtaking beauty of Northeast Oregon. Copyright © 1996 Florinsa Farms Corporation Last modified: September 26, 1996WT03-B27-67IA097-001043-B025-455http://www.florinsa.com:80/ecuador.htm 199.227.116.49 19970215080151 text/html 2542HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Saturday, 15-Feb-97 08:02:21 GMTServer: FrontPage-PWS32/1.1.2.6MIME-version: 1.0Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Monday, 21-Oct-96 17:47:36 GMTContent-length: 2345 Ecuador and Roses Ecuador and Roses . TheAndean Mountains The most beautiful roses in the world are being harvestedtoday, like everyday, on the farms of Florinsa Farms in Ecuador.Nestled in the Andean mountains outside of Quito, the farms ofFlorinsa Farms provide ideal conditions for the production ofexceptional roses. The water is nature's purest, from the snow melt and thetemperature is stable year-round. The days are long here and thespecial brilliance of sunlight at the equator is consistentthroughout the year. Beginning with these great natural blessing, Florinsa Farmshas also developed the post-harvesting technology that definesstate-of-the-art in the industry. From our breeding laboratoriesin the Netherlands to the most modern computerized irrigation andfertilization systems on our farms, we've found the perfect blendof nature and science. It's a marriage that produces roses withunusually big heads, strong straight stems, healthy leaves, andan intensity of color you simply have to see to believe. Copyright © 1996 Florinsa Farms Corporation Last modified: October 11, 1996WT03-B27-68IA097-001043-B025-489http://www.florinsa.com:80/compost.htm 199.227.116.49 19970215080204 text/html 10630HTTP/1.0 200 OKDate: Saturday, 15-Feb-97 08:02:28 GMTServer: FrontPage-PWS32/1.1.2.6MIME-version: 1.0Content-type: text/htmlLast-modified: Monday, 21-Oct-96 17:47:56 GMTContent-length: 10432 Florinsa Compost Project Harvest Residue: The Untapped Nutrient Source By Bob Baars Florinsa Farms has developed a system using worms and compostto lower costs and raise quality In the floricultural industry, fertilization not only makes upa large part of operational budgets but carries an equally highenvironmental price tag. Because production depends on economicsand consumer demand, environmentally friendlier productionmethods are becoming increasingly important. Yet not manycompanies are aware of the potential their harvest residue has asa first step to meet these demands. For Florinsa Farms inEcuador, composting provides the means to effectively managenutritional and environmental demands as well as productioncosts. Harvest Residue Benefits A common belief is that merely piling up organic matterwill eventually produce compost. Unfortunately, this concept is abroad and often incorrect generalization of a very complexmicro-biological science. Composting is an exact science with itsown rules and limitations. For it to be a successful source ofnutrients, growers must first understand the mechanisms at work.Floricultural companies produce tremendous amounts of biomass anda substantial amount, the harvest residue, remains on-farm.Growers burn, destroy or produce compost with this residue.Composting is good practice, as the residue contains valuablenutrients. As good money has been paid for these nutrients, it iscommon sense to re-apply them to the soil. However, the nutrient content is not the only considerationwhen producing compost. As crops grow, they consume organicmatter as humus from the soil. Humus content determines thefertility of a soil. Applying chemical fertilizers as the onlyform of nutrition does not add any humus-forming organic matterto the soil. Instead the soil is gradually depleted of humus andthus of its fertility. Reapplying the harvest residue as compostsaves money and replenishes valuable exported humus needed tomaintain production and quality standards. Soil Breakdown Nutrients and water are taken up through the roots inthe soil. Soil must have buffer capacity to allow storage ofnutrients: humus. This substance is made exclusively by theactivity of microorganisms transforming organic substances, crudenutrients applied to the soil, into stabilized and readilydigestible food. The presence or absence of microorganisms in thesoil is very important and determines its health status.Decreased microbial activity implies increased susceptibility todiseases and pest attacks. The management of microorganismsshould not be considered a hands-off responsibility. The image isthat they grow automatically. However, microorganisms are livingcreatures and change rapidly with changes in their livingconditions. Their presence or absence cannot be determined by simplechemical analysis. Chromatography enables the soil status to bevisualized. It produces "soil pictures" that providedata such as soil condition, structure, microbiological statusand fertility concerning a soil or compost. Chromatography canprovide a picture library of the gradual improvement ordegeneration of a soil and notably its microbiological status. Decomposers When harvest residue is piled into a heap, it is invadedby bacteria that specialize in breaking down organic compounds.Mesophilic decomposers are the first to invade. They quicklyconcentrate their efforts to heat up the pile. They increasetemperature with the energy they use to break down residue. Next, thermophilic microorganisms begin working. At the highertemperatures, mesophilic bacteria are eliminated by their ownactivity and become food for thermophilic organisms. Their hungersoon causes the temperature in the pile to peak, signaling theend of the breakdown cycle. As thermophilic microorganismsdeplete their food supply, overall activity in the heapdiminishes. While the temperature drops, several organisms arewaiting to initiate the next stage in the process: stabilization. When growers recognize the smell of good soil, they usuallyare not aware that it is actually actinomycete organisms they aresmelling. Actinomycetes are crucial to humus formation in compostas well as in the soil. These bacteria release nitrogen andcarbon equally, and they possess the ability to produceantibiotics. This is where chromatography comes in handy again,as it will "show" stabilized nutrients on die clayhumus complex as well as readily available nutrients. Thestabilized nutrients are especially important in composting. Veryfew systems stabilize nutrients sufficiently in order to preventleaching. Equally few systems provide the carefully balancedmicrobiological life that increases the health and fertility ofthe soil significantly. Composting at Florinsa Farms Several composting methods are practiced worldwide.Florinsa Farms, after several years of experimenting andconducting trials with composting and vermiculture, have nowopted for aerobic composting. They found that it is possible toproduce healthier crops with microbially active compost, reducingchemical fertilizer input and production costs significantly.Moreover, to enhance quality, they grow additional ingredientson-farm by a process that provides tons of superfluous,nutrient-rich, green material. The farms also have other benefitsfrom this system: purifying the water in the storage basins andreducing evaporation. At Florinsa Farms, management discovered that compost doesn'tjust happen, it requires skill. What is often considered to be acompost heap is in many instances the remains of a anaerobiccomposting process, where more valuable elements are lost thanare stored. Anaerobic composting is an ineffective and long-termprocess. Here mainly anaerobic bacteria are at work, and despitethe fact that compost is produced, much of the nutrient potentialis used up by the anaerobic bacteria and fungi and such compostmay produce dangerous toxins such as cadaverin! Aerobic microbial compostinq Although not many growers are aware of the aerobiccomposting process, it is a truly effective composting processthat utilizes 50 to 85 carefully selected bacteria and fungistrains and is capable of recycling harvest residue in six to tenweeks! The final result is with excellent water holding capacity,good CEC qualities and readily available stabilized nutrients. What is more, the compost has many microorganisms that willcontinue their work once applied to the soil. It provides a readymenu for plants as well as for physical decomposers such asmites, millipedes, centipedes, springtails and earthworms. But why provide food for earthworms as we can make a readyproduct such as worm compost? The answer is simple. Invermiculture, microorganisms must first decompose the harvestresidue into digestible chunks before it can pass through theworms' digestive tracts. As this takes place in rather flat beds,considerable time and space is needed to process significant quantities. With aerobic composting much less timeand space is needed to recycle all material. Also, in FlorinsaFarms' soil management system, they also want food forearthworms. Vermicompost, as a ready product, does not providethis, but aerobic compost provides a ready food to nurture theneeds of earthworms. Consider that earthworms make more nutrients(phosphorous and potassium) available, neutralize soil pHd"ugh the action of their calciferous gland, improve @e andinfiltration rates, improve soil structure, stimulate microbialactivity and although it is as yet unclear why, reduces parasiticnematode counts. All of this is free, provided you feed andmanage them. Management The more types of microorganisms in the soil, thebetter. Beneficial microorganisms need to be introduced to thesoil and fed organics to help them multiply. You must bring theirpopulation to the appropriate level. This is where compost playsa major role. You have to manage soil organisms: Nurture them, accommodatethem, and make sure they have sufficient air- everything theyneed to thrive. The result is healthy soil with strongantagonistic abilities to combat diseases and nematodes. Bydefinition this means less chemical crop protection, stabilizednutrients that will not leach and sensible economics anddecreased environmental pressure. Bob Baars is projects manager, Florinsa FarmsHolland BV, and manager for Global Horticare, Lelystad,the Netherlands, Fax (31) 320-281175 email: globalbv@pi.net . Elston, NewsNet's President... NewsNet has been one of the world's most prominent online information services for more than 15 years. Designed to keep busy knowledge workers and business executives informed of the latest news and analysis from leading publications, we have built a reputation for excellence in ease of use and our outstanding customer service. Our exclusive NewsFlash® personalized-clipping agent has been acclaimed as the most flexible and robust in the industry. Today, we offer our worldwide clients immediate access to the complete full text of more than 1000 newsletters, newswires, magazines, and specialized business sources. NewsNet is especially well known for the timeliness of its information sources. NewsNet covers more than 40 industry areas and offers access to more real-time newswires than any other online database. You'll find leading daily business publications such as American Banker, Bond Buyer, Comline (from Japan), Communications Daily, Computergram International (from the U.K.), Defense Daily, Education Daily, the Financial Times of London, Health News Daily, Newsbytes, and dozens more, as well as vital business references such as Dun & Bradstreet, Standard & Poor's and TRW Business Profiles. Unlike most Internet-based news services, all of our information is accessible in a central computer database where powerful search and retrieval capabilities can find just the news you need in seconds, without time-consuming browsing and fruitless site visits. Subscribers to our system may choose to access this information from a Windows-based graphical interface called Baton, by powerful keyboard access, or by our new World Wide Web interface. I invite you to browse through our list of Information Sources, which is organized by industry segments; take a Tour of NewsNet to see how our Baton software can put the power of our services to work for you; and check out some Case Histories explaining how other knowledge workers have made NewsNet an essential tool for success. You can even have a peek at our NewsFlash on the Web product or download our Baton software for a free trial of our proprietary online service. If you'd like personal assistance in evaluating NewsNet, or pricing information, you can send a message to sales@newsnet.com or call us at 800-952-0122 (610-527-8030 outside the U.S. and Canada). WT03-B27-102IA059-000318-B037-355http://newsnet.com:80/tour/tour1.html 205.156.212.5 19970114190457 text/html 3085HTTP/1.0 200 OKServer: Netscape-Commerce/1.12Date: Tuesday, 14-Jan-97 19:03:16 GMTLast-modified: Monday, 18-Nov-96 15:13:36 GMTContent-length: 2901Content-type: text/html Tour of NewsNet Getting Started -- System Requirements and Set-up System Requirements IBM-compatible PC with a minimum 80386 25mz processor (486 33mz recommended) 4 MB RAM minimum (8 MB recommended) A modem at 9600 bps or faster 2 MB of disk space on hard drive 3.5 inch disk drive Graphic display compatible with Microsoft Windows version 3.1 or higher such as VGA or better MS-DOS version 5.0 or later and Microsoft Windows 3.1 or later in standard or enhanced mode a mouse or comparable pointing device Setting-up Baton after loading requires the completion of three quick screens: The Setup, Modem Settings, and Login Settings screens. The Setup screen Simply click the appropriate buttons for your modem's Baud rate and com port. The default values of the other variables (Data Bits, Stop Bits, Echo, Parity and Flow Control) should be correct for most systems. Modem Settings screen This screen requires that you select your modem's make and model from a list. If you do not find your modem listed, instructions for alternatives or a method for adding your modem to the list can be accessed from a help screen displayed by pressing the F1 key in Baton. Login Settings screen Just type in your ID and password, select a network and a local phone number from a list.If you would prefer not to keep your password stored for security reasons, leave the password block blank. You will then be prompted at each new sign-on for your password. Continue to the next stop on the Tour --or-- Return to the Tour of NewsNet home page to choose your ownpath. WT03-B27-103IA059-000318-B037-372http://newsnet.com:80/tour/tour2.html 205.156.212.5 19970114190508 text/html 2650HTTP/1.0 200 OKServer: Netscape-Commerce/1.12Date: Tuesday, 14-Jan-97 19:03:26 GMTLast-modified: Monday, 18-Nov-96 15:14:01 GMTContent-length: 2466Content-type: text/html Tour of NewsNet Text Retrieval -- Automatic, Continuous, Offline Article Retrieval Imagine having a full-time researcher working for you continuously around the clock, 24-hours each day, 7 days each week, culling from over 20,000 articles and news stories daily, just those that you indicated were critical to your business decision making. NewsFlash Profiles NewsFlash Profiles The process of setting up your NewsFlash phrases is quick and easy: Identify topics of interest Create phrases (either using Boolean operators or in natural language) Identify titles, industries you wish monitored You are in total control of your phrases. You may add, delete, modify them any time, and the changes you make take immediate effect. Retrieving NewsFlash Hits Retrieving NewsFlash Hits You decide when you wish to retrieve the information -- each hour, once a day or once a month. And you decide which are important enough to read now, save for later, or delete all together. Continue to the next stop on the Tour --or-- Return to the Tour of NewsNet home page to choose your ownpath. WT03-B27-104IA059-000318-B037-390http://newsnet.com:80/tour/tour3.html 205.156.212.5 19970114190611 text/html 5893HTTP/1.0 200 OKServer: Netscape-Commerce/1.12Date: Tuesday, 14-Jan-97 19:04:10 GMTLast-modified: Monday, 18-Nov-96 15:14:27 GMTContent-length: 5709Content-type: text/html Tour of NewsNet Text Retrieval -- Interactive, On-Demand Text Retrieval When business intelligence is needed without delay, NewsNet offers subscribers powerful searching capabilities on its massive archive of business news and information. On-demand text retrieval options include: Keyword text searching Article and issue retrieval Headline scanning Text Search Keyword Text Searching To retrieve information from NewsNet that covers a topic of interest, perform a keyword text search. Start by clicking on the Text Search icon from the Main Commands and Featured Services screen. Click here if you wish to display the Text Search screen Create your search strategy by completing the [Text Search] screen that is displayed, using the following steps: Define Search Type -- Boolean or concept Construct Keyword Phrase Select Search Fields -- NewsNet allows you to decide where in the article your keywords will appear...all text, headlines only, headlines and lead paragraph only Choose Database Codes -- Identify which titles to search for your topic Select a Date or Date Range -- Select the section of the NewsNet database you would like searched according to date or date range. Conduct the Search -- Click the OK button and Baton will initiate a sign on (if you aren't already connected) and begin processing your search. Output Display -- The way your search results are displayed will depend upon which Search Type you selected. For a concept search, a bar graph will be displayed which illustrates the relevancy ranking of the retrieved articles. With a Boolean search, relevancy ranking becomes less meaningful since all articles will contain your keywords, so the graph is replaced by a simple notification of the number of articles retrieved. Retrieve Articles Retrieve Full Issues Article and Issue Retrieval Each story and article contained in the NewsNet database is assigned an accession number, which appears with the headlines that result from a Text Search, NewsFlash hits as well as a headline Scan. These numbers enable you to quickly retrieve articles of interest by simply inputting the accession number in the proper box displayed after clicking on the Retrieve Articles icon from Baton's main command screen. To retrieve the full issue of any publication on NewsNet, click on the Retrieve Full Issues icon of the Main Commands and Featured Services screen. The Retrieve Full Issues screen requires that you simply type in the title code and date of the issue requested. Click the OK button and NewsNet will retrieve and display the full issue. Scan Headlines Scan Wires Scanning Headlines and Wires Just like perusing the table of contents of a book or magazine, NewsNet allows you to scan issue headlines. Click on the Scan Headlines icon from the Main Commands and Featured Services screen. Type in the title code(s) of the publication(s) whose headlines you wish to scan and the date of the issue you wish to scan. For assistance selecting the title code(s), click the List Sources button to display the Database Codes Selection screen and double click on your selected titles. Database codes for the Scan Headlines option can consist of any combination of one or more title, industry, source, or category codes. The Scan Wires feature lets you browse through information from individual newswires by displaying a sequentially numbered list of headlines from the one or more wire services that you specify. If you find an article of interest, click on the headline to receive the full text. Continue to the next stop on the Tour --or-- Return to the Tour of NewsNet home page to choose your ownpath. WT03-B27-105IA059-000318-B038-17http://newsnet.com:80/tour/tour4.html 205.156.212.5 19970114190625 text/html 4258HTTP/1.0 200 OKServer: Netscape-Commerce/1.12Date: Tuesday, 14-Jan-97 19:04:43 GMTLast-modified: Monday, 18-Nov-96 15:14:51 GMTContent-length: 4074Content-type: text/html Tour of NewsNet Specialized Company and Industry News, Reports, and Analyses NewsNet offers subscribers access to some of the most sought after business intelligence on individual companies and industries available. Sources such as Dun & Bradstreet, TRW, Standard & Poor's, and Investext are available to the NewsNet subscriber right from the Main Commands and Featured Services screen. D & B Company Reports Dun & Bradstreet Company Reports Dun & Bradstreet, the largest business information database in the world, provides important commercial credit and background information on more than 9.5 million public and private companies in the U.S. Through NewsNet, you can access D&B's three most popular report types: the Business Information Report (BIR), the Payment Analysis Report (PAR®), and the Family Tree® Service (FTS). To access Dun & Bradstreet, simply click on the D&B icon and follow the prompts. TRW Business Profiles TRW Business Profiles TRW Business Profiles provides up-to-date trade payment histories on more than 13 million business locations in the U.S., key business facts on over 400,000 companies, and financial data supplied by Standard & Poor's on over 6,000 of the largest publicly held companies. To access TRW Business Profiles, click on the TRW icon on the Main Commands and Featured Services screen and simply follow the prompts to find the information you need. Standard & Poor's Standard & Poor's Standard & Poor's Corporation provides a family of files on NewsNet based upon its Corporation Records products. These titles offer in-depth strategic and financial information, as well as current news, on approximately 10,000 publicly held companies with securities on the New York, American, Over-the-Counter, and a variety of regional and international exchanges, including approximately 1,000 Canadian Companies. Investext Reports Investext Reports Investext provides full-text research reports on companies, industries, geographical regions, and economic issues. Covering over 35,000 companies and 54 industry categories, these reports offer extensive analysis, detailed financial data, expert forecasts, and unparalleled insight into trends and business opportunities. Updated weekly, these reports are authored by expert analysts at the world's 300 leading investment banks, brokerage firms and research companies. Investext reports are divided into 62 industry and geographical titles. Continue to the next stop on the Tour --or-- Return to the Tour of NewsNet home page to choose your ownpath. To begin, click on the ANALY$T icon. You will be brought into NewsNet's native mode. Investment ANALY$T commands are required for all selections. After a welcoming message, the Investment ANALY$T menu will appear. All selections require that a company's or mutual fund's ticker symbol be entered. If you are unsure of the ticker symbol, enter 4 from the Investment Service Menu. Once you have all the ticker symbols, select the appropriate item number from the menu to retrieve the stock quotes or charts. OAG Travel Services The OAG Electronic Edition Travel Service® OAG is a NewsNet gateway service which operates easily through OAG commands or through a menu structure. To use OAG, click on the OAG Travel Services icon. You will be brought into NewsNet's native mode. Simply follow the promptsand press F1. WT03-B27-107IA059-000318-B038-62http://newsnet.com:80/tour/tour6.html 205.156.212.5 19970114190723 text/html 2540HTTP/1.0 200 OKServer: Netscape-Commerce/1.12Date: Tuesday, 14-Jan-97 19:05:36 GMTLast-modified: Monday, 18-Nov-96 15:15:39 GMTContent-length: 2356Content-type: text/html Tour of NewsNet Native Mode Native Mode Native Mode NewsNet The Native Mode feature allows you to conduct all or part of your Baton session through NewsNet's text-based interface using native commands (e.g., Search, Scan, Display, etc.). Seasoned searchers familiar with NewsNet's native interface may wish to use native mode for searches and other features. All features and services available in Baton can be utilized in NewsNet's native mode. Click on the Native Mode icon in the Main Commands and Featured Services screen to begin your native mode session. If you are not yet connected to the NewsNet server, the connection process will begin at this point. Once the connection is established, you will be in native mode. For comprehensive information on conducting your session via native mode, refer to the NewsNet Reference Guide. To receive a copy of this guide, call NewsNet Customer Support. Online help is also available by entering HELP or a question mark at any native NewsNet prompt. You've come to the end of the Tour Return to the Tour of NewsNet home page. Issues explain how to: create a successful home page on the Internet; sell from "virtual mall" shopfronts; market with electronic brochures and CD-ROM catalogs; integrate interactive advertising with your current campaign; and reduce the risk of testing a new media. Product descriptions include detailed packaging information, keyingredients, other label copy, and retail price. All products are screened forinnovations in five areas: formulation, packaging, technology, positioning, andmeeting previously unmet needs. Selling to Kids--AD31 · Sample Issue Phillips Business Information $3.00/article; $40.00/issue Updated biweekly, from 9/18/96 (Also in PH, C-P) This biweekly newsletter covers news and practical advice on the rapidly changing kids market. In-depth coverage ofengine programs, new technology developments, and after market news isincluded. Air Cargo Report--AE02 · Sample Issue Phillips Business Information Inc. $4.00/article; $40.00/issue Updated biweekly, from 6/23/94 (Also in Phillips) Focuses on the technology, financial, competitive, and developmental aspects ofthe air cargo industry. Each issue keeps you informed of such key issues as newcargo/freight services, route developments, new markets, and critical safetyissues. Articles can be used to generate leads and opportunities, targetcompetitors, and develop pricing strategies. Air Commerce--AE40 · Sample Issue Knight-Ridder/Tribune Information Services $2.00/article; $20.00/issue Updated monthly, from 2/1/96 (No cross-referencing) A worldwide publication devoted to air cargo, small package delivery, andworldwide distribution. Air Safety Week--AE16 · Sample Issue Phillips Business Information Inc. $4.00/article; $30.00/issue Updated weekly, from 7/10/89 (Also in TS, Airlines, Phillips) Covers developments at the Federal Aviation Administration, as well asinvestigations and enforcement actions by the National Transportation SafetyBoard. Also. provides coverage of accidents and incidents under investigation bythe National Transportation Safety Board and includes a comprehensive report onair safety regulation by U.S. authorities, with summaries of all notices, rules,and other regulatory actions by the FAA. Air Safety Week Accident/Incident Log--AE17 · Sample Issue Phillips Business Information Inc. $7.00/article Available from 7/10/89--8/21/95 (Also in TS, Airlines, Phillips) Covers aviation accidents and incidents under investigation by the NationalTransportation Safety Board. Each entry provides a brief description of thecircumstances, as well as the ID number of the investigation for follow-up by theuser. Following 8/21/95, this information can be found in Air Safety Week(AE16). Air Safety Week Regulatory Log--AE18 · Sample Issue Phillips Business Information Inc. $3.00/article Available from 7/10/89--8/21/95 (Also in GT, Airlines, Phillips) Provides a comprehensive report on air safety regulation by U.S. authorities, withsummaries of all notices, rules, and other regulatory actions by the FederalAviation Administration, as well as selected items from other relevant agencies.Following 8/21/95, this information can be found in Air Safety Week (AE16). These two feeds, APDataStream Business News and AP DataStream General News, are divided into fourseparate newswire services on NewsNet, all monitored on a 24-hour basis.Information from these four services is accessible immediately through the DISPLAYand SCAN commands, and is processed continuously for NewsFlash delivery to userswho have established NewsFlash profiles. Full-text searching of all articles isavailable within one hour of release. AP DataStream Business News Wire--AP01W (Also in FI, GB, Wires, BWires) Continuous reporting on business and financial news. AP DataStream National News Wire--AP02W (Also in Wires) Continuous reporting on all domestic news other than financial and political. AP DataStream Washington News Wire--AP03W (Also in GT, PO, WashDC, Wires) Continuous reporting on political news from the U.S. capital. AP DataStream International News Wire--AP04W (Also in IT, PO, IWires, Wires) Continuous reporting on international news, including the United Nations. Mercury Computer Services Inc. $1.00/article Updated daily, four-week retention (Also in BusOps) CBD: Procurements--Services--CB01 · Sample Issue Online equivalent of the Services section of U.S. Government Procurements listingsfrom the printed edition of Commerce Business Daily. All procurement invitationsover $25,000 are listed, except for those for classified services required within15 days, services placed under existing contracts, certain utility services, andservices not to be given advance publicity (as determined by the Small BusinessAdministration). All procurement invitationsover $25,000 are listed, except for those for classified supplies, required within15 days, supplies placed under existing contracts, perishable supplies, orsupplies not to be given advance publicity (as determined by the Small BusinessAdministration). CBD: Contract Awards--Services--CB03 · Sample Issue Online equivalent of the services section of the Contract Award listings from theprinted edition of Commerce Business Daily. Lists contract awards over $25,000that are likely to result in any subcontracts. CBD: Contract Awards--Supplies--CB04 · Sample Issue Online equivalent of the services section of the Contract Award listings from theprinted edition of Commerce Business Daily. Lists contract awards over $25,000that are likely to result in any subcontracts. CBD: Special Notices--CB05 · Sample Issue Online equivalent of the special notices section of the printed edition ofCommerce Business Daily. Includes special notices of government actions affectingcommerce and standards. CBD: Foreign Government Standards--CB06 · Sample Issue Online equivalent of the Foreign Government Standards section of the printededition of Commerce Business Daily. Lists notices of proposed changes in foreignstandards and certification systems that could affect U.S. exports. To become validated for D&B, signand return the D&B NewsNet Terms of Agreement, which governs the use of thisgateway service. D&B maintains files on more than 9.5 million public and private U.S. companies.The company background and credit information in D&B's reports are compiled from awide variety of sources, such as the company's owners and/or officers; suppliersthat have dealt with the company; annual reports; public-record filings; financialinstitutions; local, state, and federal agencies; trade tapes and newspapers. Through a special gateway arrangement with Dun & Bradstreet, three of D&B's mostpopular reports--The Business Information Report, The Payment Analysis Report, andFamily Tree Service--are available on NewsNet. D&B reports are separately priced according to the schedule posted in the gatewaymenus and as outlined below. If you conduct a search but don't order a report, youwill be charged $5. Prices may be higher in Canada. The Business Information Report (BIR) provides detailed information on acompany. It may include information on a firm's history, operations, financialperformance, payment habits, special events, banking, public records, and businessbackground of management. Each report costs $62.50, U.S.; $100.00, Canada. The Payment Analysis Report (PAR) offers in-depth analysis of a company'spast and current payment habits as reported to D&B to help determine how and whena firm will pay its invoices. Each report costs $45.00 U.S.; $100.00, Canada. Family Tree Service (FTS) can help you quickly pinpoint structural tiesbetween a company's branches, divisions, or subsidiaries and its headquarters orultimate parent. Summary reports are $63 each, plus $8 per subsidiary or familymember. For details on using the D&B database, consult the Special Gateway Servicessection of the NewsNet Reference Guide. D&B is not available to NewsNetsubscribers outside the U.S. and Canada. Family Tree® and PAR® are registered trademarks ofDun & Bradstreet Inc. Transcripts of similar events in theKremlin are provided in English. A schedule of official government events inWashington also is provided. NewsNet receives Federal News Service transmissionsvia satellite and processes them for real-time delivery throughout the day. Itemsfrom this service are available immediately through the DIS PLAY and SCAN commands and are processed continuously for NewsFlash delivery.Full-text searching of all articles is available within one hour of release. Federal News Service Transcripts--FN01W (Also in GT, PO, Trscript, Wires) Continuous delivery of transcripts originating from Washington and major U.S.television news programs. Federal News Service Washington Daybook--FN02W (Also in GT, PO, WashDC, Wires ) Provides daily and weekly schedules of U.S. government events and keyprivate-sector events in the Washington area. Federal News Service Kremlin Transcripts--FN03W (Also in IT, PO, CIS, IWires, Trscript, Wires ) Verbatim transcripts, in English, of speeches and press conferences by keygovernment officials in the Russia. Federal News Service is not affiliated with the U.S. government in any way. Continuous updates during market hours Provides current and historical stock and mutual fund quotes, stock charts andtechnical stock performance indicators through a menu-driven interface. Currentquotes include the day's volume, the high, low and latest trade of the day, andthe change from the previous day's closing price. Quotes have an approximate20-minute delay. In addition to payment histories, the database includes key business facts on over40,000 companies and financial data, supplied by Standard & Poor's, on over 6,000of the largest publicly held companies. A typical report includes the actualpayment histories in 30-, 60-, and 90-day divisions, supplied by the accountsreceivables departments of thousands of contributors; key business facts such asproduct lines, SIC codes, number of employees, officers' names, and ownership; andpublic record data such as tax liens, judgments, and bankruptcies. The TRW database also includes special Health Care Premium Profile reports, whichcontain in-depth company profiles on hospitals and pharmacies, detailing ownershipand revenue information. TRW access carries additional charges, as follows: each full report is billed at$29; TRW searches that yield a menu of matches or similar matches are billed at $3when no report is selected from the menu. There is an additional charge of $9 eachfor the Health Care Premium Profile reports. For details on using the TRW database, consult the Special Gateway Servicessection of the NewsNet Reference Guide. Rita is primarily responsible for researching competitive intelligence and pricing for the marketing department at Central Illinois Public Service Company (CIPS). CIPS, a public utility, conducts all core research on an in-house level and recently began intense competitive tracking with NewsFlash. Rita likes NewsFlash for easy retrieval of the information she needs to project possible mergers or uncover services the competition may offer in the near future. "The utility area is very competitive. NewsNet helps us pinpoint the changes occurring with the competition. NewsNet helps you know your competitors, as well as you know yourself, " Rita says. "With NewsNet, I don't waste time waiting for what I need. I could go into NewsNet and find a company profile or an analysis of the latest development in the field. Another benefit is the large number of newsletters online covering the energy and utility fields and the ability to pull stories off the newswires. "We like to see what the newswires release online related to our field. Sometimes a story about a utility a thousand miles away will be a real benefit to us," she explains. Rita feels the analysis is simplified when the right information is at your fingertips and no time is wasted. "When all the needed information is in front of you, it's much easier to complete the analysis. We want to be able to make accurate projections as soon as possible- before something happens. It's how we remain competitive in the field," she adds. It's difficult to pick one instance of an excellent search- they're all excellent," she adds. Online UserJanuary/February 1997, "Monitoring the Media" by Judith Mandelbaum. "...NewsFlash from NewsNet is an excellent way to monitor breaking news forcoverage of products and companies, since NewsFlash constantly matches your tracking profiles against more than 17,000 articles that enter the service each day. NewsNet and NewsFlash have over 800 sources that include real-time, worldwide newswires, and many daily newsletters and papers. There is no limit to the number of NewsFlash topics you can monitor and the menu-driven software allows more options for customizing your profile than any other system. For instance, you can specify activation and expiration dates, ask the system to search only certain segments (full text or headlines), or sort your results. You can track against a single source, any combination of sources, or everything added to the system. When your profile is active, NewsFlash notifies you at sign-on with the name of the folder and the number of new articles. You can scan a list of new headlines and decide to view results in full, KWIC, or preview formats (the first 18-24 lines). Once you've looked at the articles, you can either delete or save them..." Internet World August 1996, "Business Without Browsers" by Larry Krumenaker. "...NewsNet has long been an industry player serving up searchable databases of industry newsletters, but it only reached the Internet in 1996. Newsletters often report trends and facts long before they hit the consumer press. This is news for insiders. NewsNet is particulary strong in the electronics and computer industry and in the fields of energy, environment, financial, international, publishing, broadcasting and telecommunications. NEWSNET EXPANDS PACIFIC-RIM CONTENT Bryn Mawr, PA (October 7, 1996) -- If your business needs timely competitive intelligence information about companies or events in the Pacific, NewsNet is the place to come. Find out what companies are expanding in Asia, what up-to-the-minute political changes could influence your strategic plans, and what your competition is doing in Singapore, China, Korea, Malaysia, Jakarta, and other far eastern locales. NewsNet is pleased to announce an agreement with Financial Times Information by which NewsNet will add approximately eighty Far Eastern titles from FTI's Asia Intelligence Wire [AIW] to its ever expanding database of global intelligence information. NewsNet welcomes the addition of sources such as: the Saigon Times and the Korean Herald which are unique to AIW, and Asiaweek, The Jakarta Post, Business Times [Singapore], The Korea Economic Daily, New Straits Times, and China News to name just a few of the many full, rich sources that are included in the new agreement. Let NewsNet "clip" personalized Pacific-rim information for your company and deliver the information to you in a NewsFlashTM folder continuously, 24 hours per day, seven days per week. Don't just stay on top of the competition, stay ahead of the competition using NewsFlashTM because you know that Timing Is EverythingTM. NewsNet, Inc., headquartered in Bryn Mawr, PA is one of the oldest online business information companies in existence. NewsNet was founded in 1982 to provide businesses with in-depth, timely hard-to-find business and industry sources. NewsNet is a pre-eminent electronic news service specializing in business information from experts inside the business. Today, NewsNet�s service has approximately 1,000 newsletters, trade journals and wire services, presented by industry and cross referenced for completeness in coverage. Here's another recent NewsNet press release... NEWSNET ANNOUNCES THE ROLLOUT OF NEW WEB PRODUCTS Bryn Mawr, PA (September 4, 1996) -- New Web-friendly services for corporate users of online, global intelligence information, automatic "clipping" services, in-depth analysis and expert opinions, and real-time current awareness data is now available. NewsNet, Inc. today announced release of new options available for users connecting via their corporate Web servers. In addition to new technology, customers can now enjoy the benefits of annual fixed fee pricing for high-volume usage. NewsNet has offered Intranet and LAN-based products for some time, and in keeping its resolution to offer the best services to its clients has developed a Web product to meet their changing needs. NewsNet knows that its many national and international customers evolve their infrastructures continuously. According to Andrew Elston, NewsNet�s President, the company is totally committed to having new technology available as customers are ready for it. At no additional charge, NewsNet designs customer specific "front doors" for each company�s account. ---NewsNet Customer Service Receives Accolades The company also continues to refine its outstanding customer support programs in order to keep clients extremely satisfied. I always feel that I�m speaking with someone who really knows NewsNet inside out and wants my search experience to be productive; something I can�t always say about some other online systems."
